authors: Baorong Chang, Hongya Liu, Lixin Xu and Chengwu Zhang
title: Statefinder Diagnostic for Phantom Model withn  $V(phi)=V_{0}exp(-lambda{phi}^2)$
abstract: We investigate the phantom field with potentialn$V(phi)=V_{0}exp(-lambda{phi}^2)$ and dark matter in the spatially flat FRWnmodel.
It has been shown by numerical calculation that there is a attractornsolution in this model.
We also apply the statefinder diagnostic to thisnphantom model.
It is shown that the evolving trajectories of this scenario innthe $s-r$ diagram is quite different form other dark energy models.n

authors: Matthew M. Glenz and Koji Uryu
title: Circular solution of two unequal mass particles in post-Minkowskin  approximation
abstract: A Fokker action for post-Minkowski approximation with the firstnpost-Newtonian correction is introduced in our previous paper, and a solutionnfor the helically symmetric circular orbit is obtained.
We present supplementalnresults for the circular solution of two unequal mass point-particles.
Circularnsolutions for selected mass ratios are found numerically, and analytic formulasnin the extreme mass ratio limit are derived.
The leading terms of the analyticnformulas agree with the first post-Newtonian formulas in this limit.n

authors: Yongjae Park, Kyung-Il Kim, Taesoo Song, Su Houng Lee, Cheuk-Yin Wong
title: The widths of quarkonia in quark gluon plasma
abstract: Recent lattice calculations showed that the quarkonia will survive beyond thenphase transition temperature, and will dissolve at different temperaturesndepending on the type of the quarkonium.
In this work, we calculate the thermalnwidth of the quarkonium at finite temperature before it dissolves into opennheavy quarks.

The input of the calculation are the parton quarkoniumndissociation cross section to NLO in QCD, the quarkonium wave function in antemperature-dependent potential from lattice QCD, and a thermal distribution ofnpartons with thermal masses.

We find that for the J/psi, the total thermalnwidth above 1.4 Tc becomes larger than 100 to 250 MeV, depending on theneffective thermal masses of the quark and gluon, which we take between 400 ton600 MeV.
Such a width corresponds to an effective dissociation cross section byngluons between 1.5 to 3.5 mb and by quarks 1 to 2 mb at 1.4 Tc.
However, atnsimilar temperatures, we find a much smaller thermal width and effective crossnsection for the upsilon.n

authors: Olof Gornerup and James P. Crutchfield
title: Primordial Evolution in the Finitary Process Soup
abstract: A general and basic model of primordial evolution--a soup of reactingnfinitary and discrete processes--is employed to identify and analyzenfundamental mechanisms that generate and maintain complex structures innprebiotic systems.
The processes--$epsilon$-machines as defined inncomputational mechanics--and their interaction networks both provide wellndefined notions of structure.
This enables us to quantitatively demonstratenhierarchical self-organization in the soup in terms of complexity.
We foundnthat replicating processes evolve the strategy of successively building highernlevels of organization by autocatalysis.
Moreover, this is facilitated by localncomponents that have low structural complexity, but high generality.
In effect,nthe finitary process soup spontaneously evolves a selection pressure thatnfavors such components.
In light of the finitary process soups generality,nthese results suggest a fundamental law of hierarchical systems: globalncomplexity requires local simplicity.n

authors: Patrick B. Hall (1), Sarah I. Sadavoy (1), Damien Hutsemekers (2),n  John E. Everett (3), Alireza Rafiee (1) ((1) York University, (2) Universityn  of Li`ege, (3) University of Wisconsin-Madison)
title: Acceleration and Substructure Constraints in a Quasar Outflow
abstract: We present observations of probable line-of-sight acceleration of a broadnabsorption trough of C IV in the quasar SDSS J024221.87+004912.6.
We alsondiscuss how the velocity overlap of two other outflowing systems in the samenobject constrains the properties of the outflows.
The Si IV doublet in eachnsystem has one unblended transition and one transition which overlaps withnabsorption from the other system.
The residual flux in the overlapping troughnis well fit by the product of the residual fluxes in the unblended troughs.
Fornthese optically thick systems to yield such a result, at least one of them mustnconsist of individual subunits rather than being a single structure withnvelocity-dependent coverage of the source.

If these subunits are identical,nopaque, spherical clouds, we estimate the cloud radius to be r = 3.9 10^15 cm.nIf they are identical, opaque, linear filaments, we estimate their width to benw = 6.5 10^14 cm.

These subunits are observed to cover the Mg II broad emissionnline region of the quasar, at which distance from the black hole the abovenfilament width is equal to the predicted scale height of the outer atmospherenof a thin accretion disk.

Insofar as that scale height is a natural size scalenfor structures originating in an accretion disk, these observations arenevidence that the accretion disk can be a source of quasar absorption systems.nBased on data from ESO program 075.B-0190(A).n

authors: Sam Tannous
title: Avoiding Rotated Bitboards with Direct Lookup
abstract: This paper describes an approach for obtaining direct access to the attackednsquares of sliding pieces without resorting to rotated bitboards.
The techniqueninvolves creating four hash tables using the built in hash arrays from anninterpreted, high level language.
The rank, file, and diagonal occupancy arenfirst isolated by masking the desired portion of the board.
The attackednsquares are then directly retrieved from the hash tables.

Maintainingnincrementally updated rotated bitboards becomes unnecessary as does all thenupdating, mapping and shifting required to access the attacked squares.nFinally, rotated bitboard move generation speed is compared with that of thendirect hash table lookup method.n

authors: Huai-Bin Zhuang, Michael Ma, Xi Dai, Fu-Chun Zhang
title: Mott Insulator - Superfluid Transitions in a Two Band Model at Finiten  Temperature and Possible Application to Supersolid 4He
abstract: We study Mott insulator - superfluid transition in a two-band boson Hubbardnmodel, which can be mapped onto a spin-1/2 XY model with spins coupled to annadditional Ising degree of freedom.
By using a modified mean field theory thatninclude the effects of phase fluctuations, we show that the transition is firstnorder at both zero and finite temperatures.
On the Mott insulator side, therenmay be reentrance in phase transition.
These features are consequences of thenunderlying transition between competing defect poor and defect rich phases.
Thenrelevance of the model and our results to supersolid 4He and cold bosonic atomsnin optical lattices are discussed.n

authors: Zhen Wu, Zhiyong Yu
title: Dynamic programming principle for one kind of stochastic recursiven  optimal control problem and Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations
abstract: In this paper, we study one kind of stochastic recursive optimal controlnproblem with the obstacle constraints for the cost function where the costnfunction is described by the solution of one reflected backward stochasticndifferential equations.

We will give the dynamic programming principle for thisnkind of optimal control problem and show that the value function is the uniquenviscosity solution of the obstacle problem for the correspondingnHamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations.n

authors: Luis Guillermo Cota, Pilar Alonso-Reyes, Pablo de la Mora
title: On the limits of surface fractal behaviour in silica. A virtualn  adsorbates simulation
abstract: A computer simulation technique, suited to replicate real adsorptionnexperiments, was applied to pure simulated silica in order to gain insight intonthe fractal regime of its surface.
The previously reported experimental fractalndimension was closely approached and the hitherto uncharted lower limit ofnfractal surface behaviour is reported herein.n

authors: Dhananjay P. Mehendale
title: On the Theory of Colorful Graphs
abstract: The theory of colorful graphs can be developed by working in Galois fieldnmodulo (p), p > 2 and a prime number.
The paper proposes a program of possiblenconversion of graph theory into a pleasant colorful appearance.
We propose tonpaint the usual black (indicating presence of an edge) and white (indicatingnabsence of an edge) edges of graphs using multitude of colors and study theirnproperties.
All colorful graphs considered here are simple, i.e.
not having anynmultiple edges or self-loops.
This paper is an invitation to the program ofngeneralizing usual graph theory in this direction.n

authors: T. Mart
title: From Pauli Principle to Hypernucleus, Neutron Star, and Econophysics
abstract: Proposed by Wolfgang Pauli more than 80 years ago, the exclusion principlenhas been proven to have a far-reaching consequence, from femtoscopic world tonmacroscopic, super-dense, and fully relativistic physics.

Starting from thisnprinciple, we discuss two interesting research topics, which have currentlyndrawn considerable attention in the nuclear- and astrophysics communities; thenhypernuclear and neutron star physics.
Special attention is given to thenelectromagnetic production of the hypertriton and the consequences of thenneutrino electromagnetic properties in dense matter.
We also touch on the newnarena which could also be fascinating for physicists; the econophysics.n

authors: M. Ibison
title: Emergent gravity from direct-action EM in a toy universe of electronsn  and positrons
abstract: We sketch the derivation of a Newtonian gravity-like force emerging from andirect-action variant of classical electromagnetism.
The binding energy is anconsequence of maximal phase correlation of the sources mediated bynapproximately monochromatic direct-action fields.

The resulting force then hasnthe character of a strong version of the van der Waals force, whose superiornstrength can be attributed to relatively coherent primary fields (compared withnthe totally incoherent effects of the ZPF).
The model also predicts thenexistence of a background having some of the character of dark energy.n

authors: Pierre Collet, Jean-Philippe Rennard
title: Stochastic Optimization Algorithms
abstract: When looking for a solution, deterministic methods have the enormousnadvantage that they do find global optima.
Unfortunately, they are verynCPU-intensive, and are useless on untractable NP-hard problems that wouldnrequire thousands of years for cutting-edge computers to explore.
In order tonget a result, one needs to revert to stochastic algorithms, that sample thensearch space without exploring it thoroughly.
Such algorithms can find veryngood results, without any guarantee that the global optimum has been reached;nbut there is often no other choice than using them.
This chapter is a shortnintroduction to the main methods used in stochastic optimization.n

authors: Yi Li, Laurent Chevillard, Gregory Eyink and Charles Meneveau
title: Matrix Exponential-Based Closures for the Turbulent Subgrid-Scale Stressn  Tensor
abstract: Two approaches for closing the turbulence subgrid-scale stress tensor innterms of matrix exponentials are introduced and compared.

The first approach isnbased on a formal solution of the stress transport equation in which thenproduction terms can be integrated exactly in terms of matrix exponentials.nThis formal solution of the subgrid-scale stress transport equation is shown tonbe useful to explore special cases, such as the response to constant velocityngradient, but neglecting pressure-strain correlations and diffusion effects.nThe second approach is based on an Eulerian-Lagrangian change of variables,ncombined with the assumption of isotropy for the conditionally averagednLagrangian velocity gradient tensor and with the `Recent Fluid Deformationn(RFD) approximation.

It is shown that both approaches lead to the same basicnclosure in which the stress tensor is expressed as the product of the matrixnexponential of the resolved velocity gradient tensor multiplied by itsntranspose.

Short-time expansions of the matrix exponentials are shown tonprovide an eddy-viscosity term and particular quadratic terms, and thus allow anreinterpretation of traditional eddy-viscosity and nonlinear stress closures.nThe basic feasibility of the matrix-exponential closure is illustrated bynimplementing it successfully in Large Eddy Simulation of forced isotropicnturbulence.
The matrix-exponential closure employs the drastic approximation ofnentirely omitting the pressure-strain correlation and other `nonlinearnscrambling terms.

But unlike eddy-viscosity closures, the matrix exponentialnapproach provides a simple and local closure that can be derived directly fromnthe stress transport equation with the production term, and using physicallynmotivated assumptions about Lagrangian decorrelation and upstream isotropy.n

authors: Ivan Zh. Stefanov, Stoytcho S. Yazadjiev, Michail D. Todorov
title: Scalar-tensor black holes coupled to Born-Infeld nonlinearn  electrodynamics
abstract: The non-existence of asymptotically flat, neutral black holes andnasymptotically flat, charged black holes in the Maxwell electrodynamics, withnnon-trivial scalar field has been proved for a large class of scalar-tensorntheories.
The no-scalar-hair theorems, however, do not apply in the case ofnnon-linear electrodynamics.

In the present work numerical solutions describingncharged black holes coupled to Born-Infeld type non-linear electrodynamics innscalar-tensor theories of gravity with massless scalar field are found.
Thencausal structure and properties of the solutions are studied, and a comparisonnbetween these solutions and the corresponding solutions in the GeneralnRelativity is made.
The presence of the scalar field leads to a much morensimple causal structure.
The present class of black holes has a single,nnon-degenerate horizon, i.e., its causal structure resembles that of thenSchwarzschild black hole.n

authors: Marco Polini, Reza Asgari, Yafis Barlas, T. Pereg-Barnea, and A.H.n  MacDonald
title: Graphene: A Pseudochiral Fermi Liquid
abstract: Doped graphene sheets are pseudochiral two-dimensional Fermi liquids withnabnormal electron-electron interaction physics.

We address graphenes Ferminliquid properties quantitatively using a microscopic random-phase-approximationntheory and comment on the importance of using exchange-correlation potentialsnbased on the properties of a chiral two-dimensional electron gas inndensity-functional-theory applications to graphene nanostructures.n

authors: Saifullah
title: Some Exact Solutions to Equations of Motion of an Incompressible Thirdn  Grade Fluid
abstract: This investigation deals with some exact solutions of the equations governingnthe steady plane motions of an incompressible third grade fluid by usingncomplex variables and complex functions.
Some of the solutions admit, asnparticular cases, all the solutions of Moro et al[1].n

authors: Yoav Lahini, Assaf Avidan, Francesca Pozzi, Marc Sorel, Roberton  Morandotti, Demetrios N. Christodoulides and Yaron Silberberg
title: Anderson localization and nonlinearity in one dimensional disorderedn  photonic lattices
abstract: We experimentally investigate the evolution of linear and nonlinear waves inna realization of the Anderson model using disordered one dimensional waveguidenlattices.
Two types of localized eigenmodes, flat-phased and staggered, arendirectly measured.
Nonlinear perturbations enhances localization in one type,nand induce delocalization in the other.
In a complementary approach, we studynthe evolution on short time scales of $delta$-like wavepackets in the presencenof disorder.
A transition from ballistic wavepacket expansion to exponentialn(Anderson) localization is observed.
We find an intermediate regime in whichnthe ballistic and localized components coexist while diffusive dynamics isnabsent.
Evidence is found for a faster transition into localization undernnonlinear conditions.n

authors: M. Sato and A. J. Sievers
title: Driven localized excitations in the acoustic spectrum of small nonlinearn  macroscopic and microscopic lattices
abstract: Both bright and dark traveling, locked, intrinsic localized modes (ILMs) havenbeen generated with a spatially uniform driver at a frequency in the acousticnspectrum of a nonlinear micromechanical cantilever array.

Complementarynnumerical simulations show that a minimum density of modes, hence array size,nis required for the formation of such locked smoothly running excitations.nAdditional simulations on a small 1-D antiferromagnetic spin system are used tonillustrate that such uniformly driven running ILMs should be a generic featurenof a nanoscale atomic lattice.n

authors: Marius Buliga
title: Microfractured media with a scale and Mumford-Shah energies
abstract: We want to understand he concentration of damage in microfractured elasticnmedia.

Due to the different scallings of the volume and area (or area andnlength in two dimensions) the traditional method of homogenization usingnperiodic arrays of cells seems to fail when applied to the Mumford-Shahnfunctional and to periodically fractured domains.n  In the present paper we are departing from traditional homogenization.
Thenmain result implies the use of Mumford-Shah energies and leads to annexplanation of the observed concentration of damage in microfractured elasticnbodies.n

authors: Takeshi Aimi and Masatoshi Imada
title: Gaussian-Basis Monte Carlo Method for Numerical Study on Ground Statesn  of Itinerant and Strongly Correlated Electron Systems
abstract: We examine Gaussian-basis Monte Carlo method (GBMC) introduced by Corney andnDrummond.
This method is based on an expansion of the density-matrix operatornrho by means of the coherent Gaussian-type operator basis Lambda and does notnsuffer from the minus sign problem.

The original method, however, often failsnin reproducing the true ground state and causes systematic errors of calculatednphysical quantities because the samples are often trapped in some metastable ornsymmetry broken states.

To overcome this difficulty, we combine thenquantum-number projection scheme proposed by Assaad, Werner, Corboz, Gull andnTroyer in conjunction with the importance sampling of the original GBMC method.nThis improvement allows us to carry out the importance sampling in thenquantum-number-projected phase-space.

Some comparisons with the previousnquantum-number projection scheme indicate that, in our method, the convergencenwith the ground state is accelerated, which makes it possible to extend thenapplicability and widen the range of tractable parameters in the GBMC method.nThe present scheme offers an efficient practical way of computation fornstrongly correlated electron systems beyond the range of system sizes,ninteraction strengths and lattice structures tractable by other computationalnmethods such as the quantum Monte Carlo method.n

authors: H. Sadeghi
title: Neutron-Deuteron System and Photon Polarization Parameter at Thermaln  Neutron Energies
abstract: Effective Field Theory(EFT) is, the unique, model independent and systematicnlow-energy version of QCD for processes involving momenta below the pion mass.nA low-energy photo-nuclear observable in three-body systems, photonnpolarization parameter at thermal neutron energies is calculated by usingnpionless EFT up to next-to-next to leading order(N$^2$LO).

In order to make ancomparative study of this model, we compared our results for photonnpolarization parameter with the realistic Argonne $v_{18}$ two-nucleon andnUrbana IX or Tucson-Melbourne three-nucleon interactions.

Three-body currentsngive small but significant contributions to some of the observables in thenneutron-deuteron radiative capture cross section at thermal neutron energies.nIn this formalism the three-nucleon forces are needed up to N$^2$LO for cut-offnindependent results.
Our result converges order by order in low energynexpansion and also cut-off independent at this order.n

authors: Fred C. MacKintosh and Alex J. Levine
title: Non-equilibrium mechanics and dynamics of motor activated gels
abstract: The mechanics of cells is strongly affected by molecular motors that generatenforces in the cellular cytoskeleton.
We develop a model for cytoskeletalnnetworks driven out of equilibrium by molecular motors exerting transientncontractile stresses.
Using this model we show how motor activity canndramatically increase the networks bulk elastic moduli.

We also show how motornbinding kinetics naturally leads to enhanced low-frequency stress fluctuationsnthat result in non-equilibrium diffusive motion within an elastic network, asnseen in recent emph{in vitro} and emph{in vivo} experiments.n

authors: Supriyo Pal, Krishna Kumar, Mahendra K. Verma, Daniele Carati, Arnabn  K. De, Vinayak Eswaran
title: Chaotic traveling rolls in Rayleigh-Benard convection
abstract: In this paper we investigate two-dimensional (2D) Rayleigh-Benardnconvection using direct numerical simulation in Boussinesq fluids of Prandtlnnumber $P = 6.8$ confined between thermally conducting plates.
We show throughnthe simulation that in a small range of reduced Rayleigh number $r$ ($770 < r <n890$) the 2D rolls move chaotically in a direction normal to the roll axis.
Thenlateral shift of the rolls may lead to global flow reversal of the convectivenmotion.

The chaotic traveling rolls are observed in simulation with {itnfree-slip} as well as {it no-slip} boundary conditions on the velocity field.nWe show that the traveling rolls and the flow reversal are due to an interplaynbetween the real and imaginary parts of the critical modes.n

authors: Simon Chelkowski, Henning Vahlbruch, Karsten Danzmann, Roman Schnabel
title: Coherent control of broadband vacuum squeezing
abstract: We present the observation of optical fields carrying squeezed vacuum statesnat sideband frequencies from 10Hz to above 35MHz.
The field was generated withntype-I optical parametric oscillation below threshold at 1064nm.
A coherent,nunbalanced classical modulation field at 40MHz enabled the generation of errornsignals for stable phase control of the squeezed vacuum field with respect to anstrong local oscillator.
Broadband squeezing of approximately -4dB was measurednwith balanced homodyne detection.

The spectrum of the squeezed field allows anquantum noise reduction of ground-based gravitational wave detectors over theirnfull detection band, regardless of whether homodyne readout or radio-frequencynheterodyne readout is used.n

authors: H.C. Mastwijk, P.V. Bartels, H.L.M. Lelieveld
title: The origin of the work function
abstract: In this paper we analyse the mechanisms responsible for the bonding ofnelectrons to metal surfaces.
We present and validate a method to measure thenenergy distribution of dense electron ensembles at ambient conditions.
We havenfound sharp structures in the energy distribution of charge confined at metalnsurfaces.
These structures correspond to the onset of space charge i.e.nelectron emission.
The threshold energy for emission increases linear with thenfree electron density.
We conclude that the work function is a direct measurenof the Hartree-Fock exchange energy.
Remarkably, the emissions that have beennobserved do not obey the Einstein-Millikan threshold relation for the photonelectric effect.
By discrimination between requirements for energy and momentumnwe deduce that electron emissions are trigged by photon momentum.

We claim thatnthe photo electric effect is the result of a phase transition in an electronngas that connects a surface bound, condensed state to a free continuum state.nThe assignment of a phase transition to the effect under consideration isnjustified by analyzing the behaviour of the Fermi-Dirac energy distributionnupon raising the Fermi level.
We predict an abrupt increment in the number ofnelectrons in the continuum that exceeds 70 orders of magnitude.
Both thenobserved threshold energy and the line shape of the transition are in goodnagreement with theoretical predictions.n

authors: Bence Toth, Balint Toth, Janos Kertesz
title: Modeling the Epps effect of cross correlations in asset prices
abstract: We review the decomposition method of stock return cross-correlations,npresented previously for studying the dependence of the correlation coefficientnon the resolution of data (Epps effect).
Through a toy model of randomnwalk/Brownian motion and memoryless renewal process (i.e.
Poisson pointnprocess) of observation times we show that in case of analytical treatability,nby decomposing the correlations we get the exact result for the frequencyndependence.
We also demonstrate that our approach produces reasonable fittingnof the dependence of correlations on the data resolution in case of empiricalndata.
Our results indicate that the Epps phenomenon is a product of the finitentime decay of lagged correlations of high resolution data, which does not scalenwith activity.
The characteristic time is due to a human time scale, the timenneeded to react to news.n

authors: S.J. Gong and Z.Q. Yang
title: Spin filtering implemented through Rashba and weak magnetic modulations
abstract: We present two theoretical schemes for spin filters in one-dimensionalnsemiconductor quantum wires with spatially modulated Rashba spin-orbit couplingn(SOC) as well as weak magnetic potential.
For case I, the SOC is periodic andnthe weak magnetic potential is applied uniformly along the wire.
Full spinnpolarizations with opposite signs are obtained within two separated energynintervals.
For case II, the weak magnetic potential is periodic while the SOCnis uniform.
An ideal negative/positive switching effect for spin polarizationnis realized by tuning the strength of SOC.
The roles of SOC, magneticnpotential, and their coupling on the spin filtering are analyzed.n

authors: Neil Bevis, Mark Hindmarsh, Martin Kunz and Jon Urrestilla
title: CMB polarization power spectra contributions from a network of cosmicn  strings
abstract: We present the first calculation of the possible (local) cosmic stringncontribution to the cosmic microwave background polarization spectra fromnsimulations of a string network (rather than a stochastic collection ofnunconnected string segments).
We use field theory simulations of the AbeliannHiggs model to represent local U(1) strings, including their radiative decaynand microphysics.
Relative to previous estimates, our calculations show a shiftnin power to larger angular scales, making the chance of a future cosmic stringndetection from the B-mode polarization slightly greater.

We explore a futurenground-based polarization detector, taking the CLOVER project as our example.nIn the null hypothesis (that cosmic strings make a zero contribution) we findnthat CLOVER should limit the string tension mu to Gmu<0.12e-6 (where G is thengravitational constant), above which it is likely that a detection would benpossible.n

authors: G. J. Qiao, K. J. Lee, B. Zhang, H. G. Wang and R. X. Xu
title: An annular gap acceleration model for $gamma$-ray emission of pulsars
abstract: If the binding energy of the pulsars surface is not so high (the case of anneutron star), both the negative and positive charges will flow out freely fromnthe surface of the star.
The annular free flow model for $gamma$-ray emissionnof pulsars is suggested in this paper.
It is emphasized that: (1).
Two kinds ofnacceleration regions (annular and core) need to be taken into account.
Thenannular acceleration region is defined by the magnetic field lines that crossnthe null charge surface within the light cylinder.

If the potential dropnin the annular region of a pulsar is high enough (normally the cases of youngnpulsars), charges in both the annular and the core regions could be acceleratednand produce primary gamma-rays.
Secondary pairs are generated in both regionsnand stream outwards to power the broadband radiations.
The potential dropnin the annular region grows more rapidly than that in the core region.
Thenannular acceleration process is a key point to produce wide emission beams asnobserved.
The advantages of both the polar cap and outer gap models arenretained in this model.
The geometric properties of the $gamma$-ray emissionnfrom the annular flow is analogous to that presented in a previous work by Qiaonet al., which match the observations well.
Since charges with differentnsigns leave the pulsar through the annular and the core regions, respectively,nthe current closure problem can be partially solved.n

authors: C.M. Arizmendi, H.G.E. Hentschel, F. Family
title: Entropic Studies of Cytoskeletal Motors Jamming
abstract: Can the different causes for disruption of intracellular transport be tracednfrom the trajectories of the molecular motors on the cytoskeletal filaments?
Wenwill attempt to answer this important question in a Monte Carlo model ofnmicrotubule-motor protein interaction from the point of view of informationntheory.n

authors: Daniel Kunth (Institut Astrophysique de Paris, France; kunth atn  iap.fr) and Goran Ostlin (Stockholm Observatory, Sweden; ostlin atn  astro.su.se)
title: Are the most metal-poor galaxies young?
abstract: We review the possibility that metallicity could provide a diagnostic for thenage of a galaxy, hence that the most metal-poor star forming galaxies in thenlocal universe may be genuinely young.
Indeed, observational evidence forndownsizing shows the average age of the stars in a galaxy to decrease withndecreasing mass and metallicity.

However, we conclude both from observationalnand theoretical viewpoints that metallicity is not an arrow of time.nConsequently the most metal poor galaxies of our local universe are notnnecessarely young.
Current observations suggest that an old stellar populationnis present in all metal-poor galaxies, although a couple of cases, e.g.
IZw18,nremain under debate.
Further observations with more sentitive equipement shouldnsettle this question in the coming years.n

authors: A. M. Gulian
title: Superconducting antenna for detection of gravitational waves
abstract: Combining the principle of magnetic flux quantization inside ansuperconducting loop and existence of rigid platforms (i.e., solids,nnon-deformable under the action of gravitational waves) a design forngravitational wave antenna is suggested.
This design could yield a non-resonantndetector, with modest sizes and capability to generate detectable signals forngravitational waves from astrophysical sources.n

authors: Kunth Daniel (Institut Astrophysique de Paris, France)
title: Starbursts and their contribution to metal enrichment
abstract: I review the properties of starburst galaxies, compare the properties of thenlocal ones with more distant starburts and examine their role in the metalnenrichment of the interstellar medium and the intergalactic-intraclusternmedium.
Metallicity is not an arrow of time and contrary to current beliefnmetal rich galaxies can also be found at high redshift.n

authors: Leonid P. Pryadko and Alexander N. Korotkov
title: Coherence of a Josephson phase qubit under partial-collapse measurement
abstract: We discuss quantum evolution of a decaying state in relation to a recentnexperiment of Katz et al.

Based on exact analytical and numerical solutions ofna simple model, we identify a regime where qubit retains coherence over anfinite time interval independently of the rates of three competing decoherencenprocesses.
In this regime, the quantum decay process can be continuouslynmonitored via a ``weak measurement without affecting the qubit coherence.n

authors: Jakob Enemark and Kim Sneppen
title: On Gene Duplication Models for Evolving Regulatory Networks
abstract: Background: Duplication of genes is important for evolution of molecularnnetworks.
Many authors have therefore considered gene duplication as a drivingnforce in shaping the topology of molecular networks.

In particular it has beennnoted that growth via duplication would act as an implicit way of preferentialnattachment, and thereby provide the observed broad degree distributions ofnmolecular networks.n  Results: We extend current models of gene duplication and rewiring bynincluding directions and the fact that molecular networks are not a result ofnunidirectional growth.
We introduce upstream sites and downstream shapes tonquantify potential links during duplication and rewiring.
We find that this innitself generates the observed scaling of transcription factors for genome sitesnin procaryotes.

The dynamical model can generate a scale-free degreendistribution, p(k)∝ 1/k^γ, with exponent γ=1 in thennon-growing case, and with γ>1 when the network is growing.n  Conclusions: We find that duplication of genes followed by substantialnrecombination of upstream regions could generate main features of geneticnregulatory networks.
Our steady state degree distribution is however to broadnto be consistent with data, thereby suggesting that selective pruning acts as anmain additional constraint on duplicated genes.
Our analysis shows that genenduplication can only be a main cause for the observed broad degreendistributions, if there is also substantial recombinations between upstreamnregions of genes.n

authors: David Lasne (CPMOH), Gerhard A. Blab (CPMOH), Stephane Berciaudn  (CPMOH), Martin Heine (PCS), Laurent Groc (PCS), Daniel Choquet (PCS),n  Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Brahim Lounis (CPMOH)
title: Single NanoParticle Photothermal Tracking (SNaPT) of 5 nm gold beads inn  live cells
abstract: Tracking individual nano-objets in live cells during arbitrary long times isnan ubiquitous need in modern biology.
We present here a method for trackingnindividual 5 nm gold nanoparticles on live cells.
It relies on the photothermalneffect and the detection of the Laser Induced Scattering around a NanoAbsorbern(LISNA).
The key point for recording trajectories at video rate is the use of antriangulation procedure.
The effectiveness of the method is tested againstnSingle fluorescent Molecule Tracking in live COS7 cells on subsecond timenscales.
We further demonstrate recordings for several minutes of AMPA receptorsntrajectories on the plasma membrane of live neurons.
SNaPT has the uniquenpotential to record arbitrary long trajectory of membrane proteins usingnnon-fluorescent nanometer sized labels.n

authors: Miloslav Znojil
title: Conditional observability
abstract: For a quantum Hamiltonian H =H(p) the observability of the energies E may benrobust (whenever all E are real at all p) or, otherwise, conditional.
Using anpseudo-Hermitian family of N-state chain models H we discuss some genericnproperties of conditionally observable spectra.n

authors: B.F. Madore (1), A. Gil de Paz (2), O. Pevunova (3), I. Thompson (1)n  ((1) Carnegie Observatories, (2) Universidad Complutense de Madrid, (3) NED,n  Caltech)
title: The Curious Case of NGC6908
abstract: The object NGC6908 was once thought to be simply a surface-brightnessnenhancement in the eastern spiral arm of the nearby spiral galaxy NGC6907.nBased on an examination of near-infrared imaging, the object is shown in factnto be a lenticular S0(6/7) galaxy hidden in the optical glare of the disk andnspiral structure of the larger galaxy.

New radial velocities of NGC6908n(3,060+/-16 (emission); 3,113+/-73 km/s (absorption)) have been obtained at thenBaade 6.5m and the duPont 2.5m telescopes at Las Campanas, Chile placingnNGC6908 at the same expansion-velocity distance as NGC6907 (3,190+/-5 km/s),neliminating the possibility of a purely chance line-of-sight coincidence.
Thenonce-enigmatic asymmetries in the disk and outer spiral structure of NGC6907nare now explained as being due to an advanced merger event.
Newly discoveredntails and debris in the outer reaches of this galaxy further support the mergernscenario for this system.

This pair of galaxies is a rather striking example ofntwo objects discovered over 100 years ago, whose true nature was lost untilnmodern detectors operating at infrared wavelengths gave us a newn(high-contrast) look.

Other examples of embedded merger remnants may alsonreveal themselves in the growing samples of near-infrared imaging of nearbyngalaxies; and a pilot study does reveal several other promising candidates fornfollow-up observations.n

authors: Stephane Berciaud (CPMOH), Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Philippe Tamaratn  (CPMOH), Brahim Lounis (CPMOH)
title: Observation of intrinsic size effects in the optical response ofn  individual gold nanoparticles
abstract: The Photothermal Heterodyne Imaging method is used to study for the firstntime the absorption spectra of individual gold nanoparticles with diametersndown to 5 nm.
Intrinsic size effects wich result in a broadening of the SurfacenPlasmon resonance are unambiguously observed.
Dispersions in the peak energiesnand homogeneous widths of the single particle resonances are revealed.
Thenexperimental results are analysed within the frame of Mie theory.n

authors: Stephane Berciaud (CPMOH), Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Brahim Lounisn  (CPMOH)
title: Photothermal Absorption Spectroscopy of Individual Semiconductorn  Nanocrystals
abstract: Photothermal heterodyne detection is used to record the firstnroom-temperature absorption spectra of single CdSe/ZnS semiconductornnanocrystals.
These spectra are recorded in the high cw excitation regime, andnthe observed bands are assigned to transitions involving biexciton and trionnstates.
Comparison with the single nanocrystals photoluminescence spectra leadsnto the measurement of spectral Stokes shifts free from ensemble averaging.n

authors: Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Catherine Tardin (CPMOH), David Boyer (CPMOH),n  Daniel Choquet (PCS), Philippe Tamarat (CPMOH), Brahim Lounis (CPMOH)
title: Single metallic nanoparticle imaging for protein detection in cells
abstract: We performed a visualization of membrane proteins labeled with 10-nm goldnnanoparticles in cells, using an all-optical method based on photothermalninterference contrast.
The high sensitivity of the method and the stability ofnthe signals allows 3D imaging of individual nanoparticles without the drawbacksnof photobleaching and blinking inherent to fluorescent markers.
A simplenanalytical model is derived to account for the measurements of the signalnamplitude and the spatial resolution.
The photothermal interference contrastnmethod provides an efficient, reproducible, and promising way to visualize lownamounts of proteins in cells by optical means.n

authors: D.G. Zarlenga, H.A. Larrondo, C.M. Arizmendi, and F. Family
title: Trapping mechanism in overdamped ratchets with quenched noise
abstract: A trapping mechanism is observed and proposed as the origin of the anomalousnbehavior recently discovered in transport properties of overdamped ratchetsnsubject to external oscillatory drive in the presence of quenched noise.
Innparticular, this mechanism is shown to appear whenever the quenched disordernstrength is greater than a threshold value.
The minimum disorder strengthnrequired for the existence of traps is determined by studying the trapnstructure in a disorder configuration space.
An approximation to the trappingnprobability density function in a disordered region of finite length includednin an otherwise perfect ratchet lattice is obtained.
The mean velocity of thenparticles and the diffusion coefficient are found to have a non-monotonicndependence on the quenched noise strength due to the presence of the traps.n

authors: B. Geyer, G.L. Klimchitskaya, V.M. Mostepanenko
title: Analytic approach to the thermal Casimir force between metal andn  dielectric
abstract: The analytic asymptotic expressions for the Casimir free energy, pressure andnentropy at low temperature in the configuration of one metal and one dielectricnplate are obtained.
For this purpose we develop the perturbation theory in ansmall parameter proportional to the product of the separation between thenplates and the temperature.

This is done using both the simplified model of annideal metal and of a dielectric with constant dielectric permittivity and fornthe realistic case of the metal and dielectric with frequency-dependentndielectric permittivities.
The analytic expressions for all related physicalnquantities at high temperature are also provided.
The obtained analytic resultsnare compared with numerical computations and good agreement is found.

Wendemonstrate for the first time that the Lifshitz theory, when applied to thenconfiguration of metal-dielectric, satisfies the requirements of thermodynamicsnif the static dielectric permittivity of a dielectric plate is finite.
If it isninfinitely large, the Lifshitz formula is shown to violate the Nernst heatntheorem.

The implications of these results for the thermal quantum field theorynin Matsubara formulation and for the recent measurements of the Casimir forcenbetween metal and semiconductor surfaces are discussed.n

authors: Vyjayanthi Chari, Ghislain Fourier, Prasad Senesi
title: Weyl modules for the twisted loop algebras
abstract: The notion of a Weyl module, previously defined for the untwisted affinenalgebras, is extended here to the twisted affine algebras.
We describe annidentification of the Weyl modules for the twisted affine algebras withnsuitably chosen Weyl modules for the untwisted affine algebras.
Thisnidentification allows us to use known results in the untwisted case to computenthe dimensions and characters of the Weyl modules for the twisted algebras.n

authors: Jean Clairambault, Stephane Gaubert, and Benoit Perthame
title: An inequality for the Perron and Floquet eigenvalues of monotonen  differential systems and age structured equations
abstract: For monotone linear differential systems with periodic coefficients, then(first) Floquet eigenvalue measures the growth rate of the system.
We define annappropriate arithmetico-geometric time average of the coefficients for which wencan prove that the Perron eigenvalue is smaller than the Floquet eigenvalue.
Wenapply this method to Partial Differential Equations, and we use it for annage-structured systems of equations for the cell cycle.
This opposition betweennFloquet and Perron eigenvalues models the loss of circadian rhythms by cancerncells.n

authors: Aminul Huq
title: Compositions of Graphs Revisited
abstract: The idea of graph compositions, which was introduced by A. Knopfmacher and M.nE.
Mays, generalizes both ordinary compositions of positive integers andnpartitions of finite sets.
In their original paper they developed formulas,ngenerating functions, and recurrence relations for composition countingnfunctions for several families of graphs.
Here we show that some of the resultsninvolving compositions of bipartite graphs can be derived more easily usingnexponential generating functions.n

authors: W. Wang, L. B. Fu, and X. X. Yi
title: Effect of Decoherence on the Dynamics of Bose-Einstein Condensates in an  Double-well Potential
abstract: We study the dynamics of a Bose-Einstein condensate in a double-wellnpotential in the mean-field approximation.
Decoherence effects are considerednby analyzing the couplings of the condensate to environments.
Two kinds ofncoupling are taken into account.

With the first kind of coupling dominated, thendecoherence can enhance the self-trapping by increasing the damping of thenoscillations in the dynamics, while the decoherence from the second kind ofncondensate-environment coupling leads to spoiling of the quantum tunneling andnself-trapping.n

authors: Junren Shi, G. Vignale, Di Xiao, Qian Niu
title: Quantum Theory of Orbital Magnetization and its Generalization ton  Interacting Systems
abstract: Based on standard perturbation theory, we present a full quantum derivationnof the formula for the orbital magnetization in periodic systems.
Thenderivation is generally valid for insulators with or without a Chern number,nfor metals at zero or finite temperatures, and at weak as well as strongnmagnetic fields.

The formula is shown to be valid in the presence ofnelectron-electron interaction, provided the one-electron energies and wavenfunctions are calculated self-consistently within the framework of the exactncurrent and spin density functional theory.n

authors: Danny Calegari
title: Word length in surface groups with characteristic generating sets
abstract: A subset of a group is characteristic if it is invariant under everynautomorphism of the group.

We study word length in fundamental groups of closednhyperbolic surfaces with respect to characteristic generating sets consistingnof a finite union of orbits of the automorphism group, and show that thentranslation length of any element with nonzero crossing number is positive, andnbounded below by a constant depending only (and explicitly) on a bound on thencrossing numbers of generating elements.
This answers a question of B. Farb.n

authors: Mark Ya. Azbel
title: Non-coding DNA programs express adaptation and its universal law
abstract: Significant fraction (98.5% in humans) of most animal genomes is non- codingndark matter.
Its largely unknown function (1-5) is related to programmingn(rather than to spontaneous mutations) of accurate adaptation to rapidlynchanging environment.
Programmed adaptation to the same universal law fornnon-competing animals from anaerobic yeast to human is revealed in the study ofntheir extensively quantified mortality (6-21).
Adaptation of animals withnremoved non-coding DNA fractions may specify their contribution to genomicnprogramming.
Emergence of new adaptation programs and their (non-Mendelian)nheredity may be studied in antibiotic mini-extinctions (22-24).
On a largenevolutionary scale rapid universal adaptation was vital for survival, andnevolved, in otherwise lethal for diverse species major mass extinctionsn(25-28).
Evolutionary and experimental data corroborate these conclusionsn(6-21, 29-32).
Universal law implies certain biological universality of diversenspecies, thus quantifies applicability of animal models to humans).
Genomicnadaptation programming calls for unusual approach to its study and impliesnunanticipated perspectives, in particular, directed biological changes.n

authors: Furong Yin
title: Neutrino mixing matrix in the 3-3-1 model with heavy leptons and $A_4$n  symmetry
abstract: We study the lepton sector in the model based on the local gauge groupn$SU(3)_cotimes SU(3)_Lotimes U(1)_X$ which do not contain particles withnexotic electric charges.
The seesaw mechanism and discrete $A_4$ symmetry arenintroduced into the model to understand why neutrinos are especially light andnthe observed pattern of neutrino mixing.
The model provides a method fornobtaining the tri-bimaximal mixing matrix in the leading order.
A non-zeronmixing angle $V_{e3}$ presents in the modified mixing matrix.n

authors: Zhengjun Wei, Peng Zhou, Xiaobao Liu, Jindong Wang, Changjun Liao,n  Jianping Guo, Rihao Li, and Songhao Liu
title: An integral gated mode single photon detector at telecom wavelengths
abstract: We demonstrate an integral gated mode single photon detector at telecomnwavelengths.
The charge number of an avalanche pulse rather than the peakncurrent is monitored for single-photon detection.

The transient spikes innconventional gated mode operation are canceled completely by integrating, whichnenables one to improve the performance of single photon detector greatly withnthe same avalanche photodiode.
This method has achieved a detection efficiencynof 29.9% at the dark count probability per gate equal to 5.57E-6/gaten(1.11E-6/ns) at 1550nm.n

authors: P. Chang, A. Spitkovsky, J. Arons
title: Long Term Evolution of Magnetic Turbulence in Relativistic Collisionlessn  Shocks: Electron-Positron Plasmas
abstract: We study the long term evolution of magnetic fields generated by ancollisionless relativistic $e^+e^-$ shock which is initially unmagnetized.

Ourn2D particle-in-cell numerical simulations show that downstream of such anWeibel-mediated shock, particle distributions are close to isotropic,nrelativistic Maxwellians, and the magnetic turbulence is highly intermittentnspatially, with the non-propagating magnetic fields forming relatively isolatednregions with transverse dimension $sim 10-20$ skin depths.
These structuresndecay in amplitude, with little sign of downstream merging.

The fields startnwith magnetic energy density $sim (0.1-0.2)$ of the upstream kinetic energynwithin the shock transition, but rapid downstream decay drives the fields tonmuch smaller values, below $10^{-3}$ of equipartition after $10^3$ skin depths.n  In an attempt to construct a theory that follows field decay to these smallernvalues, we explore the hypothesis that the observed damping is a variant ofnLandau damping in an unmagnetized plasma.

The model is based on the small valuenof the downstream magnetic energy density, which suggests that particle orbitsnare only weakly perturbed from straight line motion, if the turbulence isnhomogeneous.

Using linear kinetic theory applied to electromagnetic fields innan isotropic, relativistic Maxwellian plasma, we find a simple analytic formnfor the damping rates, $gamma_k$, in two and three dimensions for smallnamplitude, subluminous electromagnetic fields.
We find that magnetic energyndoes damp due to phase mixing of current carrying particles as $(omega_pnt)^{-q}$ with $q sim 1$.
(abridged)n

authors: Zhen-Qiang Yin, Zheng-Fu Han, Fang-Wen Sun, Guang-Can Guo
title: Decoy State Quantum Key Distribution With Modified Coherent State
abstract: To beat PNS attack, decoy state quantum key distribution (QKD) based onncoherent state has been studied widely.
We present a decoy state QKD protocolnwith modified coherent state (MCS).
By destruction quantum interference, MCSnwith fewer multi-photon events can be get, which may improve key bit rate andnsecurity distance of QKD.
Through numerical simulation, we show about 2-dBnincrement on security distance for BB84 protocol.n

authors: K. Y. Michael Wong and David Saad
title: Minimizing Unsatisfaction in Colourful Neighbourhoods
abstract: Colouring sparse graphs under various restrictions is a theoretical problemnof significant practical relevance.
Here we consider the problem of maximizingnthe number of different colours available at the nodes and theirnneighbourhoods, given a predetermined number of colours.

In the analyticalnframework of a tree approximation, carried out at both zero and finitentemperatures, solutions obtained by population dynamics give rise to estimatesnof the threshold connectivity for the incomplete to complete transition, whichnare consistent with those of existing algorithms.
The nature of the transitionnas well as the validity of the tree approximation are investigated.n

authors: Akihiro Doi, Kenta Fujisawa, Makoto Inoue, Kiyoaki Wajima, Hiroshin  Nagai, Keiichiro Harada, Kousuke Suematsu, Asao Habe, Mareki Honma, Noriyukin  Kawaguchi, Eiji Kawai, Hideyuki Kobayashi, Yasuhiro Koyama, Hiromitsu Kuboki,n  Yasuhiro Murata, Toshihiro Omodaka, Kazuo Sorai, Hiroshi Sudou, Hiroshin  Takaba, Kazuhiro Takashima, Koji Takeda, Sayaka Tamura, Ken-ichi Wakamatsu
title: Japanese VLBI Network observations of radio-loud narrow-line Seyfert 1n  galaxies
abstract: We performed phase-reference very long baseline interferometry (VLBI)nobservations on five radio-loud narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies (NLS1s) at 8.4nGHz with the Japanese VLBI Network (JVN).

Each of the five targets (RXSnJ08066+7248, RXS J16290+4007, RXS J16333+4718, RXS J16446+2619, and B3n1702+457) in milli-Jansky levels were detected and unresolved innmilli-arcsecond resolutions, i.e., with brightness temperatures higher thann10^7 K. The nonthermal processes of active galactic nuclei (AGN) activity,nrather than starbursts, are predominantly responsible for the radio emissionsnfrom these NLS1s.
Out of the nine known radio-loud NLS1s, including the onesnchosen for this study, we found that the four most radio-loud objectsnexclusively have inverted spectra.
This suggests a possibility that these NLS1snare radio-loud due to Doppler beaming, which can apparently enhance both thenradio power and the spectral frequency.n

authors: A. Szameit, Y. V. Kartashov, F. Dreisow, T. Pertsch, S. Nolte, A.n  Tunnermann, L. Torner
title: Observation of two-dimensional surface solitons in anisotropic waveguiden  arrays
abstract: We report on the experimental observation of two-dimensional surface wavesnlocalized at the edge or in the corner of femtosecond laser-written waveguidenarrays in fused silica.

Increasing the power of the input beam allows one tonobserve a clear transition from a linear diffraction pattern to localizednnonlinear surface states, which can exist at the interface only above a certainnpower threshold.n

authors: Wei Chao, Shu Luo, Zhi-zhong Xing
title: Neutrino Mixing and Leptogenesis in Type-II Seesaw Scenarios withn  Left-Right Symmetry
abstract: We propose two Type-II seesaw scenarios for the neutrino mass matrix in thenleft-right symmetric model, in which the Higgs triplet Yukawa coupling matrixntakes the appealing Friedberg-Lee texture.
We show that the nearlyntri-bimaximal neutrino mixing pattern, which is especially favored by currentnneutrino oscillation data, can be obtained from both scenarios.
We also shownthat the cosmological baryon number asymmetry can naturally be interpreted innthese two scenarios via the flavor-independent leptogenesis mechanism.n

authors: Boyko Mihov and Lyuba Slavcheva-Mihova
title: Multiband optical surface brightness profile decompositions of then  Seyfert galaxies Mrk 79 and NGC 5548
abstract: We present preliminary results of the Johnson-Cousins (U)BVRI surfacenbrightness profile decompositions of the Seyfert galaxies Mrk 79 and NGC 5548.nThe profiles were modelled as a sum of a Gaussian law for the nucleus, a Sersicnlaw for the bulge and an exponent law for the disk.
A flat bar was added to thenmodel profile of Mrk 79.
The parameters and the total magnitudes of thenstructural components were derived.n

authors: S. Udry (1), X. Bonfils (2), X. Delfosse (3), T. Forveille (3), M.n  Mayor (1), C. Perrier (3), F. Bouchy (4), C. Lovis (1), F. Pepe (1), D.n  Queloz (1), J.-L. Bertaux (5) ((1) Observatoire de Geneve, Universite den  Geneve, Switzerland, (2) Centro de Astronomia e Astrofisica da Universidaden  de Lisboa, Portugal, (3) Laboratoire dAstrophysique, Observatoire den  Grenoble, Universite J. Fourier, France, (4) Institut dAstrophysique den  Paris, France, (5) Service dAeronomie du CNRS/IPSL,n  Verri`eres-le-Buisson, France)
title: The HARPS search for southern extra-solar planets XI. Super-Earths (5 &n  8 M_Earth) in a 3-planet system
abstract: This Letter reports on the detection of two super-Earth planets in the Gl581nsystem, already known to harbour a hot Neptune.
One of the planets has a massnof 5 M_Earth and resides at the ``warm edge of the habitable zone of thenstar.
It is thus the known exoplanet which most resembles our own Earth.
Thenother planet has a 7.7 M_Earth mass and orbits at 0.25 AU from the star, closento the ``cold edge of the habitable zone.

These two new light planets aroundnan M3 dwarf further confirm the formerly tentative statistical trend for i)nmany more very low-mass planets being found around M dwarfs than aroundnsolar-type stars and ii) low-mass planets outnumbering Jovian planets around Mndwarfs.n

authors: Y. I. Izotov (1), T. X. Thuan (2) ((1) Main Astronomical Observatory,n  Kyiv, Ukraine, (2) University of Virginia, Charlottesville, USA)
title: MMT observations of new extremely metal-poor emission-line galaxies inn  the Sloan Digital Sky Survey
abstract: We present 6.5-meter MMT spectrophotometry of 20 H II regions in 13 extremelynmetal-poor emission-line galaxies selected from the Data Release 5 of the SloannDigital Sky Survey to have [O III] 4959/Hbeta < 1 and [N II] 6583/Hbeta < 0.05.nThe electron temperature-sensitive emission line [O III] 4363 is detected in 13nH II regions allowing a direct abundance determination.
The oxygen abundance innthe remaining H II regions is derived using a semi-empirical method.
The oxygennabundance of the galaxies in our sample ranges from 12+logO/H ~ 7.1 to ~ 7.8,nwith 10 H II regions having an oxygen abundance lower than 7.5.

The lowestnoxygen abundances, 12+logO/H = 7.14+/-0.03 and 7.13+/-0.07, are found in two HnII regions of the blue compact dwarf galaxy SDSSJ0956+2849=DDO 68, making itnthe second most-metal deficient emission-line galaxy known, after SBSn0335-052W.n

authors: Assaf Hasson, Alf Onshuus
title: Unstable structures definable in o-minimal theories
abstract: Let M be an o-minimal structure with elimination of imaginaries, N annunstable structure definable in M. Then there exists X, interpretable in N,nsuch that X with all the structure induced from N is o-minimal.
In particular Xnis linearly ordered.n  As part of the proof we show: Theorem 1: If the M-dimenson of N is 1 then anyn1-N-type is either strongly stable or finite by o-minimal.
Theorem 2: If N isnN-minimal then it is 1-M-dimensional.n

authors: M. Bordag
title: On the interaction of a charge with a thin plasma sheet
abstract: The interaction of the electromagnetic field with a two dimensional plasmansheet intended to describe the pi-electrons of a carbon nano-tube or a $C_{60}$nmolecule is investigated.

By integrating out first the displacement field ofnthe plasma or first the electromagnetic field different representations fornquantities like the Casimir energy are derived which are shown to be consistentnwith one another.

Starting from the covariant gauge for the electromagneticnfield it is shown that the matching conditions to which the presence of thenplasma sheet can be reduced are different from the commonly used ones.
Thendifference in the treatments does not show up in the Casimir force between twonparallel sheets, but it is present in the Casimir-Polder force between a chargenor a neutral atom and a sheet.

At once, since the plasma sheet is anregularization of the conductor boundary conditions, this sheds light on thendifference in physics found earlier in the realization of conductor boundarynconditions as thin or thick boundary conditions innPhys.Rev.D70(2004)085010.n

authors: Vasiliy Kantsler, Enrico Segre and Victor Steinberg
title: Vesicle dynamics in elongation flow: Wrinkling instability and budn  formation
abstract: We present experimental results on the relaxation dynamics of vesiclesnsubjected to a time-dependent elongation flow.
We observed and characterized annew instability, which results in the formation of higher order modes of thenvesicle shape (wrinkles), after a switch in the direction of the gradient ofnthe velocity.
This surprising generation of membrane wrinkles can be explainednby the appearance of a negative surface tension during the vesicle deflation,ndue to compression in a sign-switching transient.
Moreover, the formation ofnbuds in the vesicle membrane has been observed in the vicinity of the dynamicalntransition point.n

authors: Giulio Ciraolo and Rolando Magnanini
title: Analytical results for 2-D non-rectilinear waveguides based on then  Greens function
abstract: We consider the problem of wave propagation for a 2-D rectilinear opticalnwaveguide which presents some perturbation.
We construct a mathematicalnframework to study such a problem and prove the existence of a solution for thencase of small imperfections.
Our results are based on the knowledge of anGreens function for the rectilinear case.n

authors: Jennifer Kreft, Matthias Schroeter, Jack B. Swift, Harry L. Swinney
title: Fluidization of a vertically oscillated shallow granular layer
abstract: Molecular dynamics simulations are used to study fluidization of a verticallynvibrated, three-dimensional shallow granular layer.
As the containernacceleration is increased above g, the granular temperature and root meannsquare particle displacement increase, gradually fluidizing the layer.

Fornnearly elastic particles, or low shaking frequencies, or small layer depths,nthe end of the fluidization process is marked by an abrupt increase in thengranular temperature and rms particle displacement.
The layer is then fullynfluidized since macroscopic, fluid-like phenomena such as convection rolls andnsurface waves are observed.

Increasing the total dissipation (by eitherndecreasing the restitution coefficient or increasing the total number ofnparticles) decreases the increase in granular temperature and rms particlendisplacement at fluidization, and shifts the increase to higher accelerations.nIncreasing the frequency also decreases the magnitude of the jump, and shiftsnthe change to lower accelerations.n

authors: Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Laurent Groc (PCS), Brahim Lounis (CPMOH),n  Daniel Choquet (PCS)
title: Multiple Routes for Glutamate Receptor Trafficking: Surface Diffusionn  and Membrane Traffic Cooperate to Bring Receptors to Synapses
abstract: Trafficking of glutamate receptors into and out of synapses is criticallyninvolved in the plasticity of excitatory synaptic transmission.
Endocytosis andnexocytosis of receptors have initially been thought to account alone for thisntrafficking.
However, membrane proteins also traffic through surface lateralndiffusion in the plasma membrane.
We describe developments innelectrophysiological and optical approaches that have allowed for the real timenmeasurement of glutamate receptor surface trafficking in live neurons.

Theseninclude (i) specific imaging of surface receptors using a pH sensitivenfluorescent protein, (ii) design of a photoactivable drug to inactivate locallynsurface receptors and monitor electrophysiologically their recovery, andn(iii)application of single molecule fluorescence microscopy to directly tracknthe movement of individual surface receptors with nanometer resolution insidenand outside synapses.

Altogether, these approaches have demonstrated thatnglutamate receptors diffuse at high rates in the neuronal membrane and suggestna key role for surface diffusion in the regulation of receptor numbers atnsynapses.n

authors: Piet H M Lommerse, Gerhard A Blab, Laurent Cognet, Gregory S Harms, Bn  Ewa Snaar-Jagalska, Herman P Spaink, Thomas Schmidt
title: Single-molecule imaging of the H-ras membrane-anchor reveals domains inn  the cytoplasmic leaflet of the cell membrane
abstract: In the last decade evidence has accumulated that small domains of 50-700 nmnin diameter are located in the exoplasmic leaflet of the plasma membrane.
Mostnof these domains supposedly consist of specific sets of lipids and proteins,nand are believed to coordinate signal transduction cascades.
Whether similarndomains are also present in the cytoplasmic leaflet of the plasma membrane isnunclear so far.
To investigate the presence of cytoplasmic leaflet domains, thenH-Ras membrane-targeting sequence was fused to the C-terminus of the enhancednyellow fluorescent protein.
Using single-molecule fluorescence microscopy,ntrajectories of individual molecules diffusing in the cytoplasmic leaflet ofnthe plasma membrane were recorded.
From these trajectories, the diffusion ofnindividual membrane-anchored enhanced yellow fluorescent protein molecules wasnstudied in live cells on timescales from 5 to 200 ms.
The results show that thendiffusion of 30-40% of the molecules is constrained in domains with a typicalnsize of 200 nm.

Neither breakdown of actin nor cholesterol extraction changednthe domain characteristics significantly, indicating that the observed domainsnmay not be related to the membrane domains identified so far.n

authors: Stephane Berciaud (CPMOH), Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Gerhard A Blabn  (CPMOH), Brahim Lounis (CPMOH)
title: Photothermal heterodyne imaging of individual nonfluorescentn  nanoclusters and nanocrystals
abstract: We introduce a new, highly sensitive, and simple heterodyne optical methodnfor imaging individual nonfluorescent nanoclusters and nanocrystals.
A 2 ordernof magnitude improvement of the signal is achieved compared to previousnmethods.
This allows for the unprecedented detection of individual smallnabsorptive objects such as metallic clusters (of 67 atoms) or nonluminescentnsemiconductor nanocrystals.
The measured signals are in agreement with ancalculation based on the scattering field theory from a photothermal-inducednmodulated index of refraction profile around the nanoparticle.n

authors: Catherine Tardin (CPMOH), Laurent Cognet (CPMOH), Cecile Bats (PCS),n  Brahim Lounis (CPMOH), Daniel Choquet (PCS)
title: Direct imaging of lateral movements of AMPA receptors inside synapses
abstract: Trafficking of AMPA receptors in and out of synapses is crucial for synapticnplasticity.
Previous studies have focused on the role of endo/exocytosisnprocesses or that of lateral diffusion of extra-synaptic receptors.
We have nowndirectly imaged AMPAR movements inside and outside synapses of live neuronsnusing single-molecule fluorescence microscopy.
Inside individual synapses, wenfound immobile and mobile receptors, which display restricted diffusion.nExtra-synaptic receptors display free diffusion.
Receptors could also exchangenbetween these membrane compartments through lateral diffusion.
Glutamatenapplication increased both receptor mobility inside synapses and the fractionnof mobile receptors present in a juxtasynaptic region.
Block of inhibitoryntransmission to favor excitatory synaptic activity induced a transient increasenin the fraction of mobile receptors and a decrease in the proportion ofnjuxtasynaptic receptors.
Altogether, our data show that rapid exchange ofnreceptors between a synaptic and extra-synaptic localization occurs throughnregulation of receptor diffusion inside synapses.n

authors: Yun-Su Kim
title: C_{0}-Hilbert Modules
abstract: We provide the definition and fundamental properties of algebraic elementsnwith respect to an operator satisfying hypothesis (h).
Furthermore, we analyzenHilbert modules using C_0-operators relative to a bounded finitely connectednregion Omega in the complex plane.n

authors: J. Cao, J. L. Musfeldt, S. Mazumdar, N. Chernova, and M. S.n  Whittingham
title: Pinned Low Energy Electronic Excitation in Metal Exchanged Vanadiumn  Oxide Nanoscrolls
abstract: We measured the optical properties of mixed valent vanadium oxide nanoscrollsnand their metal exchanged derivatives in order to investigate the chargendynamics in these compounds.

In contrast to the prediction of a metallic statenfor the metal exchanged derivatives within a rigid band model, we find that theninjected charges in Mn$^{2+}$ exchanged vanadium oxide nanoscrolls are pinned.nA low-energy electronic excitation associated with the pinned carriers appearsnin the far infrared and persists at low temperature, suggesting that thennanoscrolls are weak metals in their bulk form, dominated by inhomogeneousncharge disproportionation and Madelung energy effects.n

authors: Tshilidzi Marwala, Monica Lagazio and Thando Tettey
title: An Integrated Human-Computer System for Controlling Interstate Disputes
abstract: In this paper we develop a scientific approach to control inter-countrynconflict.
This system makes use of a neural network and a feedback controlnapproach.
It was found that by controlling the four controllable inputs:nDemocracy, Dependency, Allies and Capability simultaneously, all the predictedndispute outcomes could be avoided.
Furthermore, it was observed thatncontrolling a single input Dependency or Capability also avoids all thenpredicted conflicts.
When the influence of each input variable on conflict isnassessed, Dependency, Capability, and Democracy emerge as key variables thatninfluence conflict.n

authors: Tetsufumi Tanamoto and Yoshifumi Nishi
title: Fano-Kondo effect through two-level system based on quantum dots
abstract: We theoretically study the Fano-Kondo effect in a triple quantum dot (QD)nsystem where two QDs constitute a two-level system and the other QD works in andetector with electrodes.
We found that the Fano dip is clearly modulated bynstrongly coupled QDs in a two-level system and a slow detector with noninteracting QD.
This setup suggests a new method of reading out qubit states.n

authors: Pasha Zusmanovich
title: A converse to the Second Whitehead Lemma
abstract: We show that finite-dimensional Lie algebras over a field of characteristicnzero such that the second cohomology group in every finite-dimensional modulenvanishes, are, essentially, semisimple.n

authors: Sergiu Klainerman and Igor Rodnianski
title: Sharp $L^1$ estimates for singular transport equations
abstract: We provide $L^1$ estimates for a class of transport equations containingnsingular integral operators.
While our main application is for a specificnproblem in General Relativity we believe that the phenomenon which our resultnillustrates is of a more general interest.n

authors: Jie Liu, Li-Bin Fu, Bin Liu, and Biao Wu
title: Role of Particle Interactions in the Feshbach Conversion of Fermionn  Atoms to Bosonic Molecules
abstract: We investigate the Feshbach conversion of fermion atomic pairs to condensednboson molecules with a microscopic model that accounts the repulsiveninteractions among all the particles involved.
We find that the conversionnefficiency is enhanced by the interaction between boson molecules whilensuppressed by the interactions between fermion atoms and between atom andnmolecule.
In certain cases, the combined effect of these interactions leads tona ceiling of less than 100% on the conversion efficiency even in the adiabaticnlimit.
Our model predicts a non-monotonic dependence of the efficiency on meannatomic density.
Our theory agrees well with recent experiments on $^6$Li andn$^{40}$K.n

authors: Kazue Kudo and Katsuhiro Nakamura
title: Effects of an oscillating field on pattern formation in a ferromagneticn  thin film: Analysis of patterns traveling at a low velocity
abstract: Magnetic domain patterns under an oscillating field is studied theoreticallynby using a simple Ising-like model.
We propose two ways to investigate theneffects of the oscillating field.

The first one leads to a model in whichnrapidly oscillating terms are averaged out, and the model can explain thenexistence of the maximum amplitude of the field for the appearance of patterns.nThe second one leads to a model that includes the delay of the response to thenfield, and the model suggests the existence of a traveling pattern which movesnvery slowly compared with the time scale of the driving field.n

authors: Jia-Lin Zhu and Dong Xu
title: Effective tuning of exciton polarization splitting in coupled quantumn  dots
abstract: The polarization splitting of the exciton ground state in two laterallyncoupled quantum dots under an in-plane electric field is investigated and itsneffective tuning is designed.
It is found that there are significant Starkneffect and anticrossing in energy levels.

Due to coupling between inter- andnintra-dot states, the absolute value of polarization splitting is significantlynreduced, and it could be tuned to zero by the electric field for properninter-dot separations.
Our scheme is interesting for the research on thenquantum dots-based entangled-photon source.n

authors: Victor H. Moll
title: The integrals in Gradshteyn and Rhyzik. Part 1: A family of logarithmicn  integrals
abstract: We present the evaluation of a family of logarithmic integrals.
This providesna unified proof of several formulas in the classical table of integrals by I.nS.
Gradshteyn and I. M. Rhyzik.n

abstract: We describe methods to evaluate elementary logarithmic integrals.
Thenintegrand is the product of a rational function and a linear polynomial in lnnx.n

authors: Anthony M. Bloch, Melvin Leok, Jerrold E. Marsden, Dmitry V. Zenkov
title: Controlled Lagrangians and Stabilization of Discrete Mechanical Systemsn  I
abstract: Controlled Lagrangian and matching techniques are developed for thenstabilization of relative equilibria and equilibria of discrete mechanicalnsystems with symmetry as well as broken symmetry.
Interesting new phenomenanarise in the controlled Lagrangian approach in the discrete context that arennot present in the continuous theory.

In particular, to make the discretentheory effective, one can make an appropriate selection of momentum levels or,nalternatively, introduce a new parameter into the controlled Lagrangian toncomplete the kinetic matching procedure.
Specifically, new terms in thencontrolled shape equation that are necessary for potential matching in thendiscrete setting are introduced.
The theory is illustrated with the problem ofnstabilization of the cart-pendulum system on an incline.
The paper alsondiscusses digital and model predictive controllers.n

abstract: Classification of groups generated by 3-state automata over a 2-letternalphabet started in the first paper (see http://www.arxiv.org/abs/math/0612178)nis continued.n

authors: P.O. Kazinski
title: Relativistic diffusion equation from stochastic quantization
abstract: The new scheme of stochastic quantization is proposed.
This quantizationnprocedure is equivalent to the deformation of an algebra of observables in thenmanner of deformation quantization with an imaginary deformation parameter (thenPlanck constant).
We apply this method to the models of nonrelativistic andnrelativistic particles interacting with an electromagnetic field.
In the firstncase we establish the equivalence of such a quantization to the Fokker-Plancknequation with a special force.

The application of the proposed quantizationnprocedure to the model of a relativistic particle results in a relativisticngeneralization of the Fokker-Planck equation in the coordinate space, which innthe absence of the electromagnetic field reduces to the relativistic diffusionn(heat) equation.
The stationary probability distribution functions for anstochastically quantized particle diffusing under a barrier and a particle innthe potential of a harmonic oscillator are derived.n

authors: Farhad Meshkati, Andrea J. Goldsmith, H. Vincent Poor and Stuart C.n  Schwartz
title: A Game-Theoretic Approach to Energy-Efficient Modulation in CDMAn  Networks with Delay Constraints
abstract: A game-theoretic framework is used to study the effect of constellation sizenon the energy efficiency of wireless networks for M-QAM modulation.

Annon-cooperative game is proposed in which each user seeks to choose itsntransmit power (and possibly transmit symbol rate) as well as the constellationnsize in order to maximize its own utility while satisfying its delaynquality-of-service (QoS) constraint.
The utility function used here measuresnthe number of reliable bits transmitted per joule of energy consumed, and isnparticularly suitable for energy-constrained networks.
The best-responsenstrategies and Nash equilibrium solution for the proposed game are derived.
Itnis shown that in order to maximize its utility (in bits per joule), a user mustnchoose the lowest constellation size that can accommodate the users delaynconstraint.
Using this framework, the tradeoffs among energy efficiency, delay,nthroughput and constellation size are also studied and quantified.
The effectnof trellis-coded modulation on energy efficiency is also discussed.n

authors: Farhad Meshkati, Dongning Guo, H. Vincent Poor and Stuart C. Schwartz
title: A Unified Approach to Energy-Efficient Power Control in Large CDMAn  Systems
abstract: A unified approach to energy-efficient power control is proposed forncode-division multiple access (CDMA) networks.

The approach is applicable to anlarge family of multiuser receivers including the matched filter, thendecorrelator, the linear minimum mean-square error (MMSE) receiver, and then(nonlinear) optimal detectors.
It exploits the linear relationship that hasnbeen shown to exist between the transmit power and the outputnsignal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SIR) in the large-system limit.
It isnshown that, for this family of receivers, when users seek to selfishly maximizentheir own energy efficiency, the Nash equilibrium is SIR-balanced.
In addition,na unified power control (UPC) algorithm for reaching the Nash equilibrium isnproposed.
The algorithm adjusts the users transmit powers by iterativelyncomputing the large-system multiuser efficiency, which is independent ofninstantaneous spreading sequences.
The convergence of the algorithm is provednfor the matched filter, the decorrelator, and the MMSE receiver, and isndemonstrated by means of simulation for an optimal detector.

Moreover, thenperformance of the algorithm in finite-size systems is studied and comparednwith that of a conventional power control scheme, in which user powers dependnon the instantaneous spreading sequences.n

authors: Rossella Falcone, Roberto Fiore, Mario Gravina and Alessandro Papa
title: Screening masses in the SU(3) pure gauge theory and universality
abstract: We determine from Polyakov loop correlators the screening masses in thendeconfined phase of the (3+1)d SU(3) pure gauge theory at finite temperaturennear the transition, for two different channels of angular momentum and parity.nTheir ratio is compared with that of the massive excitations with the samenquantum numbers in the 3d 3-state Potts model in the broken phase near thentransition point at zero magnetic field.

Moreover we study the inverse decaynlength of the correlation between the real parts and between the imaginarynparts of the Polyakov loop and compare the results with expectations fromnperturbation theory and mean-field Polyakov loop models.n

authors: P. F. Lazorenko, M. Mayor, M. Dominik, F. Pepe, D. Segransan and S.n  Udry
title: High-precision astrometry on the VLT/FORS1 at time scales of few days
abstract: We investigate the accuracy of astrometric measurements with the VLT/FORS1ncamera and consider potential applications.

The study is based on two-epochn(2000 and 2002/2003) frame series of observations of a selected Galactic Bulgensky region that were obtained with FORS1 during four consecutive nights each.nReductions were carried out with a novel technique that eliminates atmosphericnimage motion and does not require a distinction between targets and referencenobjects.

The positional astrometric precision was found to be limited only bynthe accuracy of the determination of the star photocentre, which is typicallyn200-300 microarcsec per single measurement for bright unsaturated starsnB=18-19.

Several statistical tests have shown that at time-scales of 1-4 nightsnthe residual noise in measured positions is essentially a white noise with nonsystematic instrumental signature and no significant deviation from a Gaussianndistribution.
Some evidence of a good astrometric quality of the VLT for framesnseparated by two years has also been found.

Our data show that the VLT withnFORS1/2 cameras can be effectively used for astrometric observations ofnplanetary microlensing events and other applications where a high accuracy isnrequired, that is expected to reach 30-40 microarcsec for a series of 50 framesn(one hours with R filter).n

authors: H. Bruntt, D. Stello, J. C. Suarez, T. Arentoft, T. R. Bedding, M. Y.n  Bouzid, Z. Csubry, T. H. Dall, Z. E. Dind, S. Frandsen, R. L. Gilliland, A.n  P. Jacob, H. R. Jensen, Y. B. Kang, S.-L. Kim, L. L. Kiss, H. Kjeldsen, J.-R.n  Koo, J.-A. Lee, C.-U. Lee, J. Nuspl, C. Sterken, R. Szabo
title: Multisite campaign on the open cluster M67. III. Delta Scuti pulsationsn  in the blue stragglers
abstract: We have made an asteroseismic analysis of the variable blue stragglers in thenopen cluster M67.
The data set consists of photometric time series from eightnsites using nine 0.6-2.1 meter telescopes with a time baseline of 43 days.
