Inntwo stars, EW Cnc and EX Cnc, we detect the highest number of frequencies (41nand 26) detected in delta Scuti stars belonging to a stellar cluster, and EWnCnc has the second highest number of frequencies detected in any delta Scutinstar.
We have computed a grid of pulsation models that take the effects ofnrotation into account.
The distribution of observed and theoretical frequenciesnshow that in a wide frequency range a significant fraction of the radial andnnon-radial low-degree modes are excited to detectable amplitudes.
Despite thenlarge number of observed frequencies we cannot constrain the fundamentalnparameters of the stars.
To make progress we need to identify the degrees ofnsome of the modes either from multi-colour photometry or spectroscopy.n

authors: U. D. Bekbaev, I. S. Rakhimov
title: On Classification of Finite Dimensional Complex Filiform Leibnizn  Algebras (Part 2)
abstract: The paper is devoted to classification problem of finite dimensional complexnnone Lie filiform Leibniz algebras.
Actually, the observations show there arentwo resources to get classification of filiform Leibniz algebras.
The first ofnthem is naturally graded none Lie filiform Leibniz algebras and the another onenis naturally graded filiform Lie algebras.
Using the first resource we get twondisjoint classes of filiform Leibniz algebras.
The present paper deals with thensecond of the above two classes, the first class has been considered in ournprevious paper.

The algebraic classification here means to specify thenrepresentatives of the orbits, whereas the geometric classification is thenproblem of finding generic structural constants in the sense of algebraicngeometry.
Our main effort in this paper is the algebraic classification.
Wensuggest here an algebraic method based on invariants.
Utilizing this method fornany given low dimensional case all filiform Leibniz algebras can be classified.nMoreover, the results can be used for geometric classification of orbits ofnsuch algebras.n

authors: Walid S. Saba
title: A Note on Ontology and Ordinary Language
abstract: We argue for a compositional semantics grounded in a strongly typed ontologynthat reflects our commonsense view of the world and the way we talk about it.nAssuming such a structure we show that the semantics of various naturalnlanguage phenomena may become nearly trivial.n

authors: I.I.Guseinov, B.A.Mamedov
title: On the accurate evaluation of overlap integrals over Slater typen  orbitals using analytical and recurrence relations
abstract: In this study, using the analytical and recurrence relations suggested by thenauthors in previous works, the new efficient and reliable program procedure fornthe overlap integrals over Slater type orbitals (STOs) is presented.
Thenproposed procedure guarantees a highly accurate evaluation of the overlapnintegrals with arbitrary values of quantum numbers, screening constants andninternuclear distances.

It is demonstrated that the computational accuracy ofnthe proposed procedure is not only dependent on the efficiency of formulas, asnhas been discussed previously, but also on a number of other factors includingnthe used program language package and solvent properties.
The numerical resultsnobtained using the algorithm described in the present work are in a completenagreement with those obtained using the alternative evaluation procedure.
Wennotice that the program works without any restrictions and in all range ofnintegral parameters.n

authors: F.Rahaman, K.Maity, P.Ghosh and K.Gayen
title: Gravitational field of a higher dimensional global monopole in Lyran  geometry
abstract: We present a five dimensional global monopole within the framework of Lyrangeometry.
Also the gravitational field of the monopole solution has beennconsidered.n

authors: Rodolfo M. Pussente, Valmir C. Barbosa
title: An algorithm for clock synchronization with the gradient property inn  sensor networks
abstract: We introduce a distributed algorithm for clock synchronization in sensornnetworks.

Our algorithm assumes that nodes in the network only know theirnimmediate neighborhoods and an upper bound on the networks diameter.nClock-synchronization messages are only sent as part of the communication,nassumed reasonably frequent, that already takes place among nodes.
Thenalgorithm has the gradient property of [2], achieving an O(1) worst-case skewnbetween the logical clocks of neighbors.

As in the case of [3,8], thenalgorithms actions are such that no constant lower bound exists on the rate atnwhich logical clocks progress in time, and for this reason the lower bound ofn[2,5] that forbids constant skew between neighbors does not apply.n

authors: T. Klose, T. McLoughlin, J. A. Minahan, K. Zarembo
title: World-sheet scattering in AdS_5 x S^5 at two loops
abstract: We study the AdS_5 x S^5 sigma-model truncated to the near-flat-space limitnto two-loops in perturbation theory.

In addition to extending previously knownnone-loop results to the full SU(2|2)^2 S-matrix we calculate the two-loopncorrection to the dispersion relation and then compute the complete two-loopnS-matrix.
The result of the perturbative calculation can be compared with thenappropriate limit of the conjectured S-matrix for the full theory and completenagreement is found.n

authors: L. DiCarlo, Yiming Zhang, D. T. McClure, D. J. Reilly, C. M. Marcus,n  L. N. Pfeiffer, K. W. West, M. P. Hanson, A. C. Gossard
title: Current Noise in Quantum Point Contacts
abstract: We present measurements of current noise in quantum point contacts as anfunction of source-drain bias, gate voltage, and in-plane magnetic field.
Atnzero bias, Johnson noise provides a measure of the electron temperature.
Atnfinite bias, shot noise at zero field exhibits an asymmetry related to the 0.7nstructure in conductance.

The asymmetry in noise evolves smoothly into thensymmetric signature of spin-resolved electron transmission at high field.nComparison to a phenomenological model with density-dependent level splittingnyields quantitative agreement.

Additionally, a device-specific contribution tonthe finite-bias noise, particularly visible on conductance plateaus (where shotnnoise vanishes), agrees quantitatively with a model of bias-dependent electronnheating.n

authors: I. Fouxon and P. Horvai
title: Single and two-particle motion of heavy particles in turbulence
abstract: We study motion of small particles in turbulence when the particle relaxationntime falls in the range of inertial time-scales of the flow.
Due to inertia,nparticles drift relative to the fluid.
We show that the drift velocity is closento the Lagrangian velocity increments of turbulence at the particle relaxationntime.

We demonstrate that the collective drift of two close particles makesnthem see local velocity increments fluctuate fast and we introduce thencorresponding Langevin description for separation dynamics.
This allows tondescribe the behavior of the Lyapunov exponent and give the analogue ofnRichardsons law for separation above viscous scale.n

authors: Hong-Van Le, Martin Panak and Jiri Vanzura
title: Manifolds admitting stable forms
abstract: In this note we give a direct method to classify all stable forms on $R^n$nas well as to determine their automorphism groups.
We show that in dimensionn6,7,8 stable forms coincide with non-degnerate forms.n  We present necessary conditions and sufficient conditions for a manifold tonadmit a stable form.
We also discuss rich properties of the geometry of suchnmanifolds.n

authors: J.M.S. Orr, P.D. Buckle, M. Fearn, C.J. Storey, L. Buckle, T. Ashley
title: A Surface-Gated InSb Quantum Well Single Electron Transistor
abstract: Single electron charging effects in a surface-gated InSb/AlInSb QW structurenare reported.
This material, due to its large g-factor and light effectivenmass, offers considerable advantages over more commonly used materials, such asnGaAs, for quantum information processing devices.

However, differences innmaterial and device technology result in significant processing challenges.nSimple Coulomb blockade and quantised confinement models are considered tonexplain the observation of conductance oscillations in these structures.
Thencharging energy is found to be comparable with the energy spectrum for singlenparticle states.n

authors: Hong-Van Le and Kaoru Ono
title: Parameterized Gromov-Witten invariants and topology of symplectomorphismn  groups
abstract: In this note we introduce parameterized Gromov-Witten invariants fornsymplectic fiber bundles and study the topology of the symplectomorphism group.nWe also give sample applications showing the non-triviality of certain homotopyngroups of some symplectomorphism groups.n

authors: Anh-Tuan Gai (INRIA Rocquencourt), Dmitry Lebedev (FT R&D), Fabienn  Mathieu (FT R&D), Fabien De Montgolfier (LIAFA), Julien Reynier (LIENS),n  Laurent Viennot (INRIA Rocquencourt)
title: Acyclic Preference Systems in P2P Networks
abstract: In this work we study preference systems natural for the Peer-to-Peernparadigm.
Most of them fall in three categories: global, symmetric andncomplementary.
All these systems share an acyclicity property.
As anconsequence, they admit a stable (or Pareto efficient) configuration, where nonparticipant can collaborate with better partners than their current ones.
Wenanalyze the representation of the such preference systems and show that anynacyclic system can be represented with a symmetric mark matrix.
This gives anmethod to merge acyclic preference systems and retain the acyclicity.
We alsonconsider such properties of the corresponding collaboration graph, asnclustering coefficient and diameter.
In particular, studying the example ofnpreferences based on real latency measurements, we observe that its stablenconfiguration is a small-world graph.n

authors: Christian Gagne (INFORMATIQUE WGZ INC.), Mich`ele Sebag (INRIAn  Futurs), Marc Schoenauer (INRIA Futurs), Marco Tomassini (ISI)
title: Ensemble Learning for Free with Evolutionary Algorithms ?
abstract: Evolutionary Learning proceeds by evolving a population of classifiers, fromnwhich it generally returns (with some notable exceptions) the singlenbest-of-run classifier as final result.
In the meanwhile, Ensemble Learning,none of the most efficient approaches in supervised Machine Learning for thenlast decade, proceeds by building a population of diverse classifiers.
EnsemblenLearning with Evolutionary Computation thus receives increasing attention.
ThenEvolutionary Ensemble Learning (EEL) approach presented in this paper featuresntwo contributions.
First, a new fitness function, inspired by co-evolution andnenforcing the classifier diversity, is presented.
Further, a new selectionncriterion based on the classification margin is proposed.
This criterion isnused to extract the classifier ensemble from the final population onlyn(Off-line) or incrementally along evolution (On-line).
Experiments on a set ofnbenchmark problems show that Off-line outperforms single-hypothesisnevolutionary learning and state-of-art Boosting and generates smallernclassifier ensembles.n

authors: M.M. Wolf, F. Verstraete, M.B. Hastings, J.I. Cirac
title: Area laws in quantum systems: mutual information and correlations
abstract: The holographic principle states that on a fundamental level the informationncontent of a region should depend on its surface area rather than on itsnvolume.
This counterintuitive idea which has its roots in the nonextensivennature of black-hole entropy serves as a guiding principle in the search fornthe fundamental laws of Planck-scale physics.

In this paper we show that ansimilar phenomenon emerges from the established laws of classical and quantumnphysics: the information contained in part of a system in thermal equilibriumnobeys an area law.
While the maximal information per unit area dependsnclassically only on the number of microscopic degrees of freedom, it mayndiverge as the inverse temperature in quantum systems.
A rigorous relationnbetween area laws and correlations is established and their explicit behaviornis revealed for a large class of quantum many-body states beyond equilibriumnsystems.n

authors: Lucas Lamata
title: Developments in entanglement theory and applications to relevantn  physical systems
abstract: This Thesis is devoted to the analysis of entanglement in relevant physicalnsystems.
Entanglement is the conducting theme of this research, though I do notndedicate to a single topic, but consider a wide scope of physical situations.

Inhave followed mainly three lines of research for this Thesis, with a series ofndifferent works each, which are, Entanglement and Relativistic Quantum Theory,nContinuous-variable entanglement, and Multipartite entanglement.n

authors: M.E. Sharina (SAO RAS), Th.H. Puzia (Herzberg Institute ofn  Astrophysics), A.S. Krylatyh (Kazan State University)
title: A globular cluster in the dwarf galaxy Sextans B
abstract: We present spectroscopic observations of a massive globular cluster in thendwarf irregular galaxy Sextans B, discovered by us on Hubble Space TelescopenWide Field and Planetary Camera 2 (HST WFPC2) images.
Long-slit spectra werenobtained with the SCORPIO spectrograph on the the 6-m telescope at the SpecialnAstrophysical observatory of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
We determine age,nmetallicity and alpha-element abundance ratio for the globular cluster to be $n2 pm 1$ Gyr, $-1.35 pm 0.25$ dex, and $ 0.1 pm 0.1$ dex, respectively.
Mainnphotometric and structural parameters of it were determined using our surfacenphotometry on the HST images.
The mass ($sim 10^5 M sun$), luminosity andnstructural parameters appear to be typical for the globular clusters in our ownnGalaxy.
Our findings shed a new light on the evolutionary history of Sextans B.n

authors: D0 Collaboration: V. Abazov, et al
title: Measurement of the Lambda_b lifetime in the exclusive decay Lambda_b ton  J/psi Lambda
abstract: We have measured the Lambda_b lifetime using the exclusive decay Lambda_b tonJ/psi Lambda, based on 1.2 fb-1 of data collected with the D0 detector duringn2002-2006.

From 171 reconstructed Lambda_b decays, where the J/psi and Lambdanare identified via the decays J/psi to mu+ mu- and Lambda to p pi, we measurednthe Lambda_b lifetime to be tau(Lambda_b) = 1.218(+0.130,-0.115)(stat) +/-n0.042(syst)ps.

We also measured the B0 lifetime in the decay B0 to J/psi(mu+nmu-)K0_S(pi+ pi-) to be tau(B0) = 1.501(+0.078,-0.074)(stat) +/ -0.050(syst)ps,nyielding a lifetime ratio of tau(Lambda_b)/tau(B0) = 0.811(+0.096,-0.087)(stat)n+/ -0.034(syst).

These measurements are consistent with the current worldnaverages and support the shorter lifetime of the Lambda_b with respect to Bnmesons, in contrast to another recent measurement of significant precision.n

authors: P. dAvezac, G. Dubus, B. Giebels
title: Cascading on extragalactic background light
abstract: High-energy gamma-rays propagating in the intergalactic medium can interactnwith background infrared photons to produce e+e- pairs, resulting in thenabsorption of the intrinsic gamma-ray spectrum.
TeV observations of the distantnblazar 1ES 1101-232 were thus recently used to put an upper limit on theninfrared extragalactic background light density.
The created pairs cannupscatter background photons to high energies, which in turn may pair produce,nthereby initiating a cascade.
The pairs diffuse on the extragalactic magneticnfield (EMF) and cascade emission has been suggested as a means for measuringnits intensity.
Limits on the IR background and EMF are reconsidered taking intonaccount cascade emissions.

The cascade equations are solved numerically.nAssuming a power-law intrinsic spectrum, the observed 100 MeV - 100 TeVnspectrum is found as a function of the intrinsic spectral index and thenintensity of the EMF.
Cascades emit mainly at or below 100 GeV.
The observednTeV spectrum appears softer than for pure absorption when cascade emission isntaken into account.
The upper limit on the IR photon background is found to benrobust.
Inversely, the intrinsic spectra needed to fit the TeV data arenuncomfortably hard when cascade emission makes a significant contribution tonthe observed spectrum.
An EMF intensity around 1e-8 nG leads to ancharacteristic spectral hump in the GLAST band.
Higher EMF intensities divertnthe pairs away from the line-of-sight and the cascade contribution to thenspectrum becomes negligible.n

authors: C. Casagrande
title: Quasi elementary contractions of Fano manifolds
abstract: Let X be a smooth complex Fano variety.
We define and study quasinelementary contractions of fiber type f: X -> Y.

These have the property thatnrho(X) is at most rho(Y)+rho(F), where rho is the Picard number and F is angeneral fiber of f. In particular any elementary extremal contraction of fiberntype is quasi elementary.
We show that if Y has dimension at most 3 and Picardnnumber at least 4, then Y is smooth and Fano; if moreover rho(Y) is at least 6,nthen X is a product.
This yields sharp bounds on rho(X) when dim(X)=4 and X hasna quasi elementary contraction, and other applications in higher dimensions.n

authors: Yi-hong Gao, Jonathan P. Shock, Wei-shui Xu and Ding-fang Zeng
title: A Note on Chiral Symmetry Breaking from Intersecting Branes
abstract: In this paper, we will consider the chiral symmetry breaking in thenholographic model constructed from the intersecting brane configuration, andninvestigate the Nambu-Goldstone bosons associated with this symmetry breaking.n

authors: S. D. Badger (Saclay, SPhT), E. W. N. Glover (IPPP, Durham U.), Kaspern  Risager (Bohr Inst.)
title: One-loop phi-MHV amplitudes using the unitarity bootstrap
abstract: We consider a Higgs boson coupled to gluons via the five-dimensionalneffective operator H Tr G_{munu}G^{munu} produced by considering the heavy topnquark limit of the one-loop coupling of Higgs and gluons in the standard model.nWe treat H as the real part of a complex field phi that couples to the selfdualngluon field strengths and compute the one-loop corrections to amplitudesninvolving phi, two colour adjacent negative helicity gluons and an arbitrarynnumber of positive helicity gluons - the so-called phi-MHV amplitudes.

We usenfour-dimensional unitarity to construct the cut-containing contributions andnthe recently developed recursion relations to obtain the rational contributionnfor an arbitrary number of external gluons.
We solve the recursion relationsnand give explicit results for up to four external gluons.
These amplitudes arenrelevant for Higgs plus jet production via gluon fusion in the limit where thentop quark mass is large compared to all other scales in the problem.n

authors: Andrea Borch, Rainer Spurzem, Jarrod Hurley
title: NBODY meets stellar population - The HYDE-PARC Project
abstract: N-body simulations give us a rough idea of how the shape of a simulatednobject appears in three-dimensional space.
From an observational point of viewnthis may give us a misleading picture.
The faint stars may be the most commonnstars in the system but the morphological information obtained by observationsnof an object may be dominated by the color properties of the bright stars.
Duento dynamical effects, such as energy equipartition, different masses of starsnmay populate different regions in the object.
Since stars are evolving in massnthe stellar evolution may also influence the dynamics of the system.
Hence, ifnone is interested in simulating what the morphology will look like through antelescope, one needs to simulate in addition evolving stars and weight them byntheir luminosity.
Therefore we need to combine simulations of the dynamicalnevolution and a stellar population synthesis at the same time.
For thendynamical evolution part we use a parallel version of a direct N-body code,nNBODY6++.
This code also includes stellar evolution.
We link the parametersnfrom this stellar evolution routine to the BaSeL 2.0 stellar library.
Fornisolated clusters we found results assimilable to standard stellar populationnsynthesis codes such as the PEGASE code.
For clusters in a tidal field we foundnthat the integrated colors become relatively bluer due to energy equipartitionneffects.
In the time shortly before dissolution of the cluster the stellar M/Lnratio becomes lower compared to isolated clusters.
We compared the results ofnour simulations to integrated spectra of galactic globular clusters.

For thencluster NGC 1851 we found good agreement between simulation and observation.nFor extragalactic clusters in M81 and M31 we looked at medium band spectralnenergy distributions and found for some clusters also a good agreement.n

authors: Outi Elina Maasalo
title: The Gehring Lemma in Metric Spaces
abstract: We present a proof for the Gehring lemma in a metric measure space endowednwith a doubling measure.
As an application we show the self improving propertynof Muckenhoupt weights.n

authors: M.V. Garzelli
title: A fully microscopical simulation of nuclear collisions by a new QMDn  model
abstract: Nucleon-ion and ion-ion collisions at non relativistic bombarding energiesncan be described by means of Monte Carlo approaches, such as those based on thenQuantum Molecular Dynamics (QMD) model.
We have developed a QMD code, tonsimulate the fast stage of heavy-ion reactions, and we have coupled it to thende-excitation module available in the FLUKA Monte Carlo transport andninteraction code.
The results presented in this work span the projectilenbombarding energy range within 200 - 600 MeV/A, allowing to investigate thencapabilities and limits of our non-relativistic QMD approach.n

authors: Kostas Skenderis, Paul K. Townsend and Antoine Van Proeyen
title: Domain-wall/Cosmology correspondence in adS/dS supergravity
abstract: We realize the domain-wall/cosmology correspondence forn(pseudo)supersymmetric domain walls (cosmologies) in the context ofnfour-dimensional supergravity.

The OSp(2|4)-invariant anti-de Sitter (adS)nvacuum of a particular N=2 Maxwell-Einstein supergravity theory is shown toncorrespond to the OSp(2^*|2,2)-invariant de Sitter (dS) vacuum of a particularnpseudo-supergravity model, with `twisted reality conditions on spinors.

Morengenerally, supersymmetric domain walls of the former model correspond tonpseudo-supersymmetric cosmologies of the latter model, with time-dependentnpseudo-Killing spinors that we give explicitly.n

authors: Andria Rogava, Grigol Gogoberidze and Stefaan Poedts
title: On over-reflection and generation of Gravito-Alfven waves in solar-typen  stars
abstract: The dynamics of linear perturbations is studied in magnetized plasma shearnflows with a constant shearing rate and with gravity-induced stratification.nThe general set of linearized equations is derived and the two-dimensional casenis considered in detail.
The Boussinesq approximation is used in order tonexamine relatively small-scale perturbations of low-frequency modes:nGravito-Alfven waves (GAW) and Entropy Mode (EM) perturbations.
It is shownnthat for flows with arbitrary shearing rate there exists a finite time intervalnof non-adiabatic evolution of the perturbations.
The non-adiabatic behaviornmanifests itself in a twofold way, viz.
by the over-reflection of the GAWs andnby the generation of GAWs from EM perturbations.
It is shown that thesenphenomena act as efficient transformers of the equilibrium flow energy into thenenergy of the perturbations for moderate and high shearing rate solar plasmanflows.
Efficient generation of GAW by EM takes place for shearing rates aboutnan order of magnitude smaller than necessary for development of a shearninstability.
The latter fact could have important consequences for the problemnof angular momentum redistribution within the Sun and solar-type stars.n

authors: Seong Chan Park (Seoul National University)
title: Orbifold GUT inflation
abstract: We consider a scenario of cosmological inflation coming from a grand unifiedntheory in higher dimensional orbifold.

Flatness of the potential isnautomatically guaranteed in this orbifold setup thanks to the nonlocality ofnthe Wilson line on higher dimensions and the local quantum gravitationalncorrections are exponentially suppressed.

The spectral index of scalarnperturbation (n_s =0.92 - 0.97) and a significant production of gravitationalnwaves are predicted (r= T/S= 0.01 - 0.12) in the perturbative regime of gaugeninteraction, (1/g_4 = (5-20) X 2 pi R Mpl) where the size of compactificationnis constrained (R Mpl = 20- 45) by the measurement of scalar power spectrumn(Delta_R = 5 X 10^-5).n

authors: Li Ma, Lin Zhao
title: Sharp thresholds of blow-up and global existence for the coupledn  nonlinear Schrodinger system
abstract: In this paper, we establish two new types of invariant sets for the couplednnonlinear Schrodinger system on $mathbb{R}^n$, and derive two sharp thresholdsnof blow-up and global existence for its solution.
Some analogous results fornthe nonlinear Schrodinger system posed on the hyperbolic space $mathbb{H}^n$nand on the standard 2-sphere $mathbb{S}^2$ are also presented.
Our argumentsnand constructions are improvements of some previous works on this direction.
Atnthe end, we give some heuristic analysis about the strong instability of thensolitary waves.n

authors: Nicolas Fournier
title: Smoothness of the law of some one-dimensional jumping S.D.E.s withn  non-constant rate of jump
abstract: We consider a one-dimensional jumping Markov process ${X^x_t}_{t geq 0}$,nsolving a Poisson-driven stochastic differential equation.
We prove that thenlaw of $X^x_t$ admits a smooth density for $t>0$, under some regularity andnnon-degeneracy assumptions on the coefficients of the S.D.E.
To our knowledge,nour result is the first one including the important case of a non-constant ratenof jump.
The main difficulty is that in such a case, the map $x mapsto X^x_t$nis not smooth.
This seems to make impossible the use of Malliavin calculusntechniques.
To overcome this problem, we introduce a new method, in which thenpropagation of the smoothness of the density is obtained by analytic arguments.n

authors: Prabuddha Sanyal, Subhra Sen Gupta, Nandan Pakhira, H. R.n  Krishnamurthy, D. D. Sarma and T. V. Ramakrishnan
title: Unusual doping and temperature dependence of photoemission spectra fromn  manganites
abstract: A recent, major, puzzle in the core-level photoemission spectra of dopednmanganites is the observation of a 1-2 eV wide shoulder with intensity varyingnwith temperature T as the square of the magnetization over a T scale of ordern200K, an order of magnitude less than electronic energies.
This is addressednand resolved here, by extending a recently proposed two electron fluid l-bnmodel for these systems to include core-hole effects.
The shoulder arises fromna rapid redistribution of e_g electron density, as a function of T, between thenhighly localized (l) and band-like (b) states.
Furthermore, our theory leads tona correspondence between spectral changes due to increasing doping andndecreasing T, as experimentally observed.n

authors: B.M. Barbashov, L.A. Glinka, V.N. Pervushin, A.F. Zakharov
title: Higgs effect in Conformal Cosmology & Supernova Data
abstract: The formulation of the Higgs effect is studied in thenGlashow--Weinberg--Salam Standard Model, where the constant part of the Higgsnpotential is identified with the zeroth mode of the Higgs field.
In this model,nthe Coleman--Weinberg effective potential obtained from the vacuum--vacuumntransition amplitude is equal to unity at the extremum.
This extremumnimmediately removes tremendous vacuum cosmological density and predicts mass ofnHiggs field.

In this model, the kinetic energy density of the Higgs field andnany scalar field can be treated as the rigid state origin that explainsnSupernova data in the conformal cosmology without the $Lambda$ term.n

authors: P.M.W. Kalberla, L. Dedes, J. Kerp, U. Haud
title: Dark matter in the Milky Way, II. the HI gas distribution as a tracer ofn  the gravitational potential
abstract: Context.
Gas within a galaxy is forced to establish pressure balance againstngravitational forces.
The shape of an unperturbed gaseous disk can be used tonconstrain dark matter models.
Aims.
We derive the 3-D HI volume densityndistribution for the Milky Way out to a galactocentric radius of 40 kpc and anheight of 20 kpc to constrain the Galactic mass distribution.
Methods.
We usednthe Leiden/Argentine/Bonn all sky 21-cm line survey.
The transformation fromnbrightness temperatures to densities depends on the rotation curve.
We explorednseveral models, reflecting different dark matter distributions.
Each of thesenmodels was set up to solve the combined Poisson-Boltzmann equation in anself-consistent way and optimized to reproduce the observed flaring.

Results.nBesides a massive extended halo of M ~ 1.8 10^{12} Msun, we find anself-gravitating dark matter disk with M=2 to 3 10^{11} Msun, including a darknmatter ring at 13 < R < 18.5 kpc with M = 2.2 to 2.8 10^{10} Msun.
Thenexistence of the ring was previously postulated from EGRET data and coincidesnwith a giant stellar structure that surrounds the Galaxy.
The resulting MilkynWay rotation curve is flat up to R~27 kpc and slowly decreases outwards.
Thenhi gas layer is strongly flaring.
The HWHM scale height is 60 pc at R = 4 kpcnand increases to ~2700$ pc at R=40 kpc.
Spiral arms cause a noticeable imprintnon the gravitational field, at least out to R = 30 kpc.
Conclusions.
Our massnmodel supports previous proposals that the giant stellar ring structure is duento a merging dwarf galaxy.

The fact that the majority of the dark matter in thenMilky Way for $R la 40$ kpc can be successfully modeled by a self-gravitatingnisothermal disk raises the question of whether this massive disk may have beenncaused by similar merger events in the past.n

authors: Wenhua Hai, Guishu Chong, Jianwen Song
title: Stabilities of one-dimensional stationary states of Bose-Einsteinn  condensates
abstract: We explore the dynamical stabilities of a quasi-one dimensional (1D)nBose-Einstein condensate (BEC) consisting of fixed $N$ atoms withntime-independent external potential.

For the stationary states with zero flowndensity the general solution of the perturbed time evolution equation isnconstructed, and the stability criterions concerning the initial conditions andnsystem parameters are established.
Taking the lattice potential case as annexample, the stability and instability regions on the parameter space arenfound.
The results suggest a method for selecting experimental parameters andnadjusting initial conditions to suppress the instabilities.n

authors: Biqin Huang (1), Douwe J. Monsma (2), and Ian Appelbaum (1) ((1)n  University of Delaware, (2) Cambridge NanoTech Inc.)
title: Spin lifetime in silicon in the presence of parasitic electronic effects
abstract: A hybrid ferromagnet/semiconductor device is used to determine a lower boundnon the spin lifetime for conduction electrons in silicon.

We use spinnprecession to self-consistently measure the drift velocity vs. drift field ofnspin-polarized electrons and use this electronic control to change the transitntime between electron injection and detection.

A measurement of normalizednmagnetocurrent as a function of drift velocity is used with a simplenexponential-decay model to argue that the lifetime obtained (~2 ns) isnartificially lowered by electronic effects and is likely orders of magnitudenhigher.n

authors: Hideki Maekawa, Kohsuke Tsubakihara, Hiroshi Matsumiya, Akira Ohnishi
title: Cascade hypernuclear production spectra at J-PARC
abstract: We predict cascade hypernuclear production spectra expected in thenforthcoming J-PARC experiment.

In the Greens function method of the distortednwave impulse wave approximation with the local optimal Fermi averagingnt-matrix, we can describe the Xi production spectra in the continuum and boundnstate region reasonably well.
Predictions to the high resonlution spectra atnJ-PARC suggest hat we should observe Xi bound state peak structure in (K-,K+)nspectra in light nuclear targets such as 12C and 27Al.n

authors: Roland Axelsson, Martin Lange, and Rafal Somla
title: The Complexity of Model Checking Higher-Order Fixpoint Logic
abstract: Higher-Order Fixpoint Logic (HFL) is a hybrid of the simply typednlambda-calculus and the modal lambda-calculus.

This makes it a highlynexpressive temporal logic that is capable of expressing various interestingncorrectness properties of programs that are not expressible in the modalnlambda-calculus.n  This paper provides complexity results for its model checking problem.
Innparticular we consider those fragments of HFL built by using only types ofnbounded order k and arity m. We establish k-fold exponential time completenessnfor model checking each such fragment.

For the upper bound we use fixpointnelimination to obtain reachability games that are singly-exponential in thensize of the formula and k-fold exponential in the size of the underlyingntransition system.
These games can be solved in deterministic linear time.

As ansimple consequence, we obtain an exponential time upper bound on the expressionncomplexity of each such fragment.n  The lower bound is established by a reduction from the word problem fornalternating (k-1)-fold exponential space bounded Turing Machines.

Since therenare fixed machines of that type whose word problems are already hard withnrespect to k-fold exponential time, we obtain, as a corollary, k-foldnexponential time completeness for the data complexity of our fragments of HFL,nprovided m exceeds 3.
This also yields a hierarchy result in expressive power.n

authors: O. Esquivel and B. Fuchs
title: Dynamical friction force exerted on spherical bodies
abstract: We present a rigorous calculation of the dynamical friction force exerted onna spherical massive perturber moving through an infinite homogenous system ofnfield stars.

By calculating the shape and mass of the polarization cloudninduced by the perturber in the background system, which decelerates the motionnof the perturber, we recover Chandrasekhars drag force law with a modifiednCoulomb logarithm.
As concrete examples we calculate the drag force exerted onna Plummer sphere or a sphere with the density distribution of a Hernquistnprofile.
It is shown that the shape of the perturber affects only the exactnform of the Coulomb logarithm.
The latter converges on small scales, becausenencounters of the test and field stars with impact parameters less than thensize of the massive perturber become inefficient.
We confirm this way earliernresults based on the impulse approximation of small angle scatterings.n

authors: Stijn Bruers
title: Testing entropy production hypotheses in non-linear steady states
abstract: In the last few decades, some hypotheses for entropy production (EP)nprinciples have been forwarded as possible candidates for organizationalnprinciples in non-linear non- equilibrium systems.

Two important hypothesesnwill be studied: the maximum entropy production (MaxEP) principle that claimsnthat the selected steady state has the highest EP, and the gradient responsenprinciple that claims that the EP of the selected steady state (maximally)nincreases when the external thermodynamic driving force increases.
We willnformulate these hypotheses more rigorously and present a simple chemicalnreaction model to test these hypotheses.

With the help of this model, we willnclearly demonstrate that there are different MaxEP hypotheses being discussednin the literature and we will look at some parts in the literature where thesendifferences are not always clarified.
Furthermore, our chemical model will be angeneral counter example to all of these MaxEP and gradient response hypotheses.n

authors: L. Fernandez-Jambrina
title: Hidden past of dark energy cosmological models
abstract: In this paper we analyse the possibility of having homogeneous isotropicncosmological models with observers reaching $t=infty$ in finite proper time.nIt is shown that just observationally-suggested dark energy models withn$win(-5/3,-1)$ show this feature and that they are endowed with an exoticncurvature singularity.
Furthermore, it is shown that non-accelerated observersnin these models may experience a duration of the universe as short as desirednby increasing their linear momentum.
A subdivision of phantom models in twonfamilies according to this behavior is suggested.n

authors: Athanasios Batakis, Benoit Testud
title: Multifractal Analysis of inhomogeneous Bernoulli products
abstract: We are interested to the multifractal analysis of inhomogeneous Bernoullinproducts which are also known as coin tossing measures.
We give conditionsnensuring the validity of the multifractal formalism for such measures.
Onnanother hand, we show that these measures can have a dense set of phasentransitions.n

authors: K.J. Resch, P. Puvanathasan, J.S. Lundeen, M.W. Mitchell, and K.n  Bizheva
title: Classical dispersion-cancellation interferometry
abstract: Even-order dispersion cancellation, an effect previously identified withnfrequency-entangled photons, is demonstrated experimentally for the first timenwith a linear, classical interferometer.
A combination of a broad bandwidthnlaser and a high resolution spectrometer was used to measure the intensityncorrelations between anti-correlated optical frequencies.

Only 14% broadeningnof the correlation signal is observed when significant material dispersion,nenough to broaden the regular interferogram by 4250%, is introduced into onenarm of the interferometer.n

authors: H.W. Braden and V.Z. Enolski
title: Monopoles, Curves and Ramanujan
abstract: We develop the Ercolani-Sinha construction of SU(2) monopoles and make thisneffective for (a five parameter family of centred) charge 3 monopoles.
Innparticular we show how to solve the transcendental constraints arising on thenspectral curve.
For a class of symmetric curves the transcendental constraintsnbecome a number theoretic problem and a recently proven identity of Ramanujannprovides a solution.n

authors: Ryan Budney, Alexandra Mozgova
title: An obstruction to a knot being deform-spun via Alexander polynomials
abstract: We show that if a co-dimension two knot is deform-spun from anlower-dimensional co-dimension 2 knot, there are constraints on the Alexandernpolynomials.
In particular this shows, for all n, that not all co-dimension 2nknots in S^n are deform-spun from knots in S^{n-1}.n

authors: Ali Saif M. Hassan and Pramod S. Joag
title: Separability Criterion for multipartite quantum states based on then  Bloch representation of density matrices
abstract: We give a new separability criterion, a necessary condition for separabilitynof $N$-partite quantum states.
The criterion is based on the Blochnrepresentation of a $N$-partite quantum state and makes use of multilinearnalgebra, in particular, the matrization of tensors.

Our criterion applies ton{it arbitrary} $N$-partite quantum states inn$mathcal{H}=mathcal{H}^{d_1}otimes mathcal{H}^{d_2} otimes ... otimesnmathcal{H}^{d_N}.$ The criterion can test whether a $N$-partite state isnentangled and can be applied to different partitions of the $N$-partite system.nWe provide examples that show the ability of this criterion to detectnentanglement.
We show that this criterion can detect bound entangled states.

Wenprove a sufficiency condition for separability of a 3-partite state,nstraightforwardly generalizable to the case $N > 3,$ under certain condition.nWe also give a necessary and sufficient condition for separability of a classnof $N$-qubit states which includes $N$-qubit PPT states.n

authors: Jan Olzem
title: Signatures of SUSY Dark Matter at the LHC and in the Spectra of Cosmicn  Rays
abstract: This thesis discusses the search for supersymmetry at the future Large HadronnCollider (LHC) and the ongoing construction of one of the four large LHCnexperiments, the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS), and focuses on the detection ofnsignals from the annihilation of supersymmetric dark matter in the spectra ofncosmic rays.n  Measurements of cosmic ray antiparticles, such as positrons, can imposenstrong constraints on the nature of new physics beyond the Standard Model.nHowever, cosmic ray positron measurements are experimentally very challengingndue to the vast proton background.

A novel approach of positron identificationnwith the space-borne AMS-01 experiment, namely through the detection ofnbremsstrahlung conversion in a silicon microstrip detector, is introduced.nBremsstrahlung from protons is suppressed by a factor of more than 3*10^6 withnrespect to positrons.

The results of the positron measurement show that thenbremsstrahlung approach extends the sensitivity range of AMS-01 to positronnmomenta up to 50 GeV/c, which is far beyond the original scope of thenexperiment.
At momenta above 8 GeV/c there is indication for a positronnoverabundance with respect to model predictions for purely secondary positronnproduction.

Therefore, the AMS-01 data lend further weight to the hints of anpositron overabundance seen in the data from earlier experiments.n  The positron fraction measurements from the most recent experiments arencombined with the results of this analysis, giving the most precise positronnfraction data yet available.n

authors: L. Fuhrmann, J. A. Zensus, T. P. Krichbaum, E. Angelakis, A. C. S.n  Readhead
title: Simultaneous Radio to (Sub-) mm-Monitoring of Variability and Spectraln  Shape Evolution of potential GLAST Blazars
abstract: The Large Area Telescope (LAT) instrument onboard GLAST offers a tremendousnopportunity for future blazar studies.

In order to fully benefit from itsncapabilities and to maximize the scientific return from the LAT, it is of greatnimportance to conduct dedicated multi-frequency monitoring campaigns that willnresult comprehensive observations.

Consequently, we initiated an effort tonconduct a GLAST-dedicated, quasi-simultaneous, broad-band flux-density (andnpolarization) monitoring of potential GLAST blazars with the Effelsberg andnOVRO radio telescopes (11cm to 7mm wavelength).

Here, we present a shortnoverview of these activities which will complement the multi-wavelengthsnactivities of the GLAST/LAT collaboration towards the low-energy radio bands.nFurther we will give a brief outlook including the extension of thisncoordinated campaign towards higher frequencies and future scientific aims.n

authors: Jean-Baptiste Masson (LOB), Guilhem Gallot (LOB)
title: Extra energy coupling through subwavelength hole arrays via stochasticn  resonance
abstract: Interaction between metal surface waves and periodic geometry ofnsubwavelength structures is at the core of the recent but crucial renewal ofninterest in plasmonics.

One of the most intriguing points is the observation ofnabnormal strong transmission through these periodic structures, which cannexceed by orders of magnitude the classical transmission given by the fillingnfactor of the plate.
The actual paradigm is that this abnormal transmissionnarises from the periodicity, and then that such high transmission shouldndisappear in random geometries.
Here, we show that extra energy can be couplednthrough the subwavelength structure by adding a controlled quantity of noise tonthe position of the apertures.
This result can be modelled in the statisticalnframework of stochastic resonance.
The evolution of the coupled energy withnrespect to noise gives access to the extra energy coupled at the surface of thensubwavelength array.n

authors: R Springell, S W Zochowski, R C C Ward, M R Wells, S D Brown, Ln  Bouchenoire, F Wilhelm, S Langridge, W G Stirling and G H Lander
title: A study of uranium-based multilayers: I. Fabrication and structuraln  characterisation
abstract: This paper addresses the structural characterisation of a series of U/Fe,nU/Co and U/Gd multilayers.

X-ray reflectivity has been employed to investigatenthe layer thickness and roughness parameters along the growth direction andnhigh-angle diffraction measurements have been used to determine the crystalnstructure and orientation of the layers.

For the case of uranium/transitionnmetal systems, the interfaces are diffuse and the transition metals are presentnin a polycrystalline form of their common bulk phases with a preferrednorientation along the closest packed planes; Fe, bcc (110) and Co, hcp (001),nrespectively.
The uranium is present in a poorly crystalline orthorhombic,nalpha-U state.
In contrast, the U/Gd multilayers have sharp interfaces withnnegligible intermixing of atomic species, and have a roughness, which isnstrongly dependent on the gadolinium layer thickness.
Diffraction spectranindicate a high degree of crystallinity in both U and Gd layers withnintensities consistent with the growth of a novel hcp U phase, stabilised bynthe hcp gadolinium layers.n

authors: Alexey K. Mazur
title: The Worm-Like Chain Theory And Bending Of Short DNA
abstract: The probability distributions for bending angles in double helical DNAnobtained in all-atom molecular dynamics simulations are compared withntheoretical predictions.

The computed distributions remarkably agree with thenworm-like chain theory for double helices of one helical turn and longer, andnqualitatively differ from predictions of the semi-elastic chain model.
Thencomputed data exhibit only small anomalies in the apparent flexibility of shortnDNA and cannot account for the recently reported AFM data (Wiggins et al,nNature nanotechnology 1, 137 (2006)).
It is possible that the current atomisticnDNA models miss some essential mechanisms of DNA bending on intermediate lengthnscales.

Analysis of bent DNA structures reveals, however, that the bendingnmotion is structurally heterogeneous and directionally anisotropic on thenintermediate length scales where the experimental anomalies were detected.nThese effects are essential for interpretation of the experimental data andnthey also can be responsible for the apparent discrepancy.n

authors: Wei Huang, Wang Xu, Mu-Lin Yan
title: Backward Compton Scattering and QED with Noncommutative Plane in then  Strong Uniform Magnetic Field
abstract: In the strong uniform magnetic field, the noncommutative plane (NCP) causednby the lowest Landau level (LLL) effect, and QED with NCP (QED-NCP) arenstudied.
Being similar to the condensed matter theory of quantum Hall effect,nan effective filling factor $f(B)$ is introduced to character the possibilitynthat the electrons stay on the LLL.

The analytic and numerical results of thendifferential cross section for the process of backward Compton scattering innthe accelerator with unpolarized or polarized initial photons are calculated.nThe existing data of BL38B2 in Spring-8 have been analyzed roughly and comparednwith the numerical predictions primitively.
We propose a precise measurement ofnthe differential cross sections of backward Compton scattering in a strongnperpendicular magnetic field, which may lead to reveal the effects of QED-NCP.n

authors: Nigel P. Byott and G. Griffith Elder
title: On the necessity of new ramification breaks
abstract: Ramification invariants are necessary, but not in general sufficient, tondetermine the Galois module structure of ideals in local number fieldnextensions.
This insufficiency is associated with elementary abeliannextensions, where one can define a refined ramification filtration -- one withnmore ramification breaks [JNTB 17 (2005)].
The first refined break number comesnfrom the usual ramification filtration and is therefore necessary.
Here wenstudy the second refined break number.n

authors: Gregory Derfel, Peter J. Grabner, Fritz Vogl
title: Complex asymptotics of Poincare functions and properties of Julia sets
abstract: The asymptotic behaviour of the solutions of Poincares functional equationn  $f(lambda z)=p(f(z))$ ($lambda>1$) for $p$ a real polynomial of degreen  $geq2$ is studied in angular regions of the complex plain.
The constancy ofnan occurring periodic function is characterised in terms of geometricnproperties of the Julia set of $p$.
For real Julia sets we give inequalitiesnfor multipliers of Pommerenke-Levin-Yoccoz type.
The distribution of zeros ofn$f$ is related to the harmonic measure on the Julia set of $p$.n

authors: G. Bonvicini, et al, CLEO Collaboration
title: Dalitz Plot Analysis of the D+ --> pi- pi+ pi+ Decay
abstract: Using 281 pb^{-1} of data recorded by the CLEO-c detector in e^+e^-ncollisions at the psi(3770), corresponding to 0.78 million D^+D^- pairs, weninvestigate the substructure of the decay D^+ to pi^- pi^+ pi^+ using thenDalitz plot technique.
We find that our data are consistent with the followingnintermediate states: rho(770)pi^+, f_2(1270)pi^+, f_0(1370)pi^+, f_0(1500)pi^+,nf_0(980) pi^+, and sigma pi^+.
We confirm large S wave contributions at low pinpi mass.
We set upper limits on contributions of other possible intermediatenstates.
We consider three models of the pi pi S wave and find that all of themnadequately describe our data.n

authors: P. Sjolund, S. J. H. Petra, C. M. Dion, H. Hagman, S. Jonsell, and A.n  Kastberg
title: Characterisation of a three-dimensional Brownian motor in opticaln  lattices
abstract: We present here a detailed study of the behaviour of a three dimensionalnBrownian motor based on cold atoms in a double optical lattice [P. Sjolund etnal., Phys.
Rev.
Lett.
This includes both experiments andnnumerical simulations of a Brownian particle.
The potentials used are spatiallynand temporally symmetric, but combined spatiotemporal symmetry is broken bynphase shifts and asymmetric transfer rates between potentials.
The diffusion ofnatoms in the optical lattices is rectified and controlled both in direction andnspeed along three dimensions.
We explore a large range of experimentalnparameters, where irradiances and detunings of the optical lattice lights arenvaried within the dissipative regime.
Induced drift velocities in the order ofnone atomic recoil velocity have been achieved.n

authors: G.J.D. Petrie, J.W.S. Blokland and R. Keppens
title: Magnetohydrostatic solar prominences in near-potential coronal magneticn  fields
abstract: We present numerical magnetohydrostatic solutions describing thengravitationally stratified, bulk equilibrium of cool, dense prominence plasmanembedded in a near-potential coronal field.

These solutions are calculatednusing the FINESSE magnetohydrodynamics equilibrium solver and describe thenmorphologies of magnetic field distributions in and around prominences and thencool prominence plasma that these fields support.

The equilibrium condition fornthis class of problem is usually different in distinct subdomains, separated bynfree boundaries, across which solutions are matched by suitable continuity ornjump conditions describing force balance.

We employ our precise finite elementnelliptic solver to calculate solutions not accessible by previous analyticalntechniques with temperature or entropy prescribed as free functions of thenmagnetic flux function, including a range of values of the polytropic index,ntemperature variations mainly across magnetic field lines and photosphericnfield profiles sheared close to the polarity inversion line.

Out of the manynexamples computed here, perhaps the most noteworthy is one which reproducesnprecisely the three-part structure often encountered in observations: a coolndense prominence within a cavity/flux rope embedded in a hot corona.

Thenstability properties of these new equilibria, which may be relevant to solarneruptions, can be determined in the form of a full resistive MHD spectrum usingna companion hyperbolic stability solver.n

authors: Vasily Ogryzko
title: Erwin Schroedinger, Francis Crick and epigenetic stability
abstract: Schroedingers book What is Life?
is widely credited for having played ancrucial role in development of molecular and cellular biology.
My essaynrevisits the issues raised by this book from the modern perspective ofnepigenetics and systems biology.

I contrast two classes of potential mechanismsnof epigenetic stability: epigenetic templating and systems biologynapproaches, and consider them from the point of view expressed by Schroedinger.nI also discuss how quantum entanglement, a nonclassical feature of quantumnmechanics, can help to address the problem of small numbers that leadnSchroedinger to promote the idea of molecular code-script for explanation ofnstability of biological order.n

authors: Sergei V. Kalinin, Brian J. Rodriguez, Stephen Jesse, Katyayani Seal,n  Roger Proksch, Sophia Hohlbauch, Irene Revenko, Gary Lee Thompson, Alexey A.n  Vertegel
title: Towards local electromechanical probing of cellular and biomolecularn  systems in a liquid environment
abstract: Electromechanical coupling is ubiquitous in biological systems with examplesnranging from simple piezoelectricity in calcified and connective tissues tonvoltage-gated ion channels, energy storage in mitochondria, andnelectromechanical activity in cardiac myocytes and outer hair cell stereocilia.nPiezoresponse force microscopy (PFM) has originally emerged as a technique tonstudy electromechanical phenomena in ferroelectric materials, and in recentnyears, has been employed to study a broad range of non-ferroelectric polarnmaterials, including piezoelectric biomaterials.
At the same time, thentechnique has been extended from ambient to liquid imaging on modelnferroelectric systems.

Here, we present results on local electromechanicalnprobing of several model cellular and biomolecular systems, including insulinnand lysozyme amyloid fibrils, breast adenocarcinoma cells, andnbacteriorhodopsin in a liquid environment.
The specific features of SPMnoperation in liquid are delineated and bottlenecks on the route towardsnnanometer-resolution electromechanical imaging of biological systems arenidentified.n

authors: Naceur Gaaloul (PPM, LSAMA), Amine Jaouadi (PPM, LSAMA), Mouradn  Telmini (LSAMA), Laurence Pruvost (LAC), Eric Charron (PPM)
title: Optical Devices for Cold Atoms and Bose-Einstein Condensates
abstract: The manipulation of cold atoms with optical fields is a very promisingntechnique for a variety of applications ranging from laser cooling and trappingnto coherent atom transport and matter wave interferometry.
Optical fields havenalso been proposed as interesting tools for quantum information processing withncold atoms.
In this paper, we present a theoretical study of the dynamics of ancold 87Rb atomic cloud falling in the gravity field in the presence of twoncrossing dipole guides.
The cloud is either deflected or split between the twonbranches of this guide.
We explore the possibilities of optimization of thisndevice and present preliminary results obtained in the case of zero-temperaturendilute Bose-Einstein condensates.n

authors: Pablo Arrighi, Renan Fargetton, Zizhu Wang
title: Intrinsically universal one-dimensional quantum cellular automata in twon  flavours
abstract: We give a one-dimensional quantum cellular automaton (QCA) capable ofnsimulating all others.
By this we mean that the initial configuration and thenlocal transition rule of any one-dimensional QCA can be encoded within theninitial configuration of the universal QCA.
Several steps of the universal QCAnwill then correspond to one step of the simulated QCA.
The simulation preservesnthe topology in the sense that each cell of the simulated QCA is encoded as angroup of adjacent cells in the universal QCA.
The encoding is linear and hencendoes not carry any of the cost of the computation.
We do this in two flavours:na weak one which requires an infinite but periodic initial configuration and anstrong one which needs only a finite initial configuration.
KEYWORDS: Quantumncellular automata, Intrinsic universality, Quantum computation.n

authors: Christine Noot-Huyghe (IRMA)
title: Un theor`eme de Beilinson-Bernstein pour les D-modulesn  arithmetiques
abstract: One proves a Beilinson-Bernstein theorem in the context of arithmeticnD-modules introduced by Berthelot, for flag varieties.
This generalizes in thenarithmetic context previous results of Brylinski-Kashiwara andnBeilinson-Bernstein in the complex case.n

authors: Andreas Mueller and Bernd Aschenbach
title: Non-monotonic orbital velocity profiles around rapidly rotatingn  Kerr-(anti-)de Sitter black holes
abstract: It has been recently demonstrated that the orbital velocity profile aroundnKerr black holes in the equatorial plane as observed in the locallynnon-rotating frame exhibits a non-monotonic radial behaviour.

We show here thatnthis unexpected minimum-maximum feature of the orbital velocity remains if thenKerr vacuum is generalized to the Kerr-de Sitter or Kerr-anti-de Sitter metric.nThis is a new general relativity effect in Kerr spacetimes with non-vanishingncosmological constant.
Assuming that the profile of the orbital velocity isnknown, this effect constrains the spacetime parameters.n

authors: F. Martinez-Vidal (On behalf of the BaBar Collaboration)
title: Measurement of the CKM angle gammma with B-+ ->D^(*)[K0s pi- pi+]K^(*)-+n  decays in BaBar
abstract: We report on the measurement of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa angle gammanthrough a Dalitz analysis of neutral D decays to K0s pi- pi+ in the processesnB-+ -> D^(*) K-+ and B-+ -> D K^*-+, D^* -> D pi0, D gamma, with the Babarndetector at the SLAC PEP-II e^+ e^- asymmetric-energy collider.n

authors: S.T. Perez-Merchancano, G. E. Marques, and L.E. Bolivar-Marinez
title: Optical Transitions in New Trends Organic Materials
abstract: The PTCDA (3,4,9,10-Perylene-tetracarboxylic dianhydride) and the NTCDAn(1,4,5,8-Naphtalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride) are aromatic, stable, planarnand highly symmetric with unusual electrical properties.

The PTCDA is ansemiconductor organic crystalline of particular interest due to its excellentnproperties and electronic potential that are used in optoelectronic devices andnthe NTCDA it is monoclinic and its space group is similar to that of the PTCDA.nRecently, alternate layers of PTCDA and NTCDA were growth forming multiplenstructures of quantum wells showing a new class of materials with new opticnlineal properties.
Some have assured that their big utilities would be centerednin the construction of diodes and of possible guides of waves.

We have carriednout calculations semi-empirical of the electronic structures and of opticnproperties of the PTCDA and of the NTCDA that show us that they are structuresnhighly orderly polymeric, semiconductors in a negative load state (chargenstate= -2)n

authors: Gary R. Goldstein
title: Dick Dalitz: Examples of His Contributions to Particle Physics
abstract: Dick Dalitz produced lasting contributions to particle physics for 50 years.nAlong with Dalitz pairs, Dalitz plots and CDD poles, he did major work innparity violation, hyperon resonance identification, the quark model, andnhypernuclei.

These topics will be summarized, with some emphasis on thenauthors collaboration with Dalitz on quark spin and fragmentationncorrelations, and, particularly, the work on the identification of the topnquark and its mass.
Short biographical information is interspersed.
This papernis based on a presentation at the International School of Subnuclear Physics,nErice 2006.n

authors: A. Fleszar, M. Potthoff, W. Hanke
title: Electronic structure of zinc-blende MnTe within the GW approximation
abstract: Using the local spin-density approximation (LSDA) and the (nonnself-consistent) GW approach, the (quasi-particle) band structure is calculatednfor MnTe in zinc-blende geometry.
Different parameters characterizing thenelectronic structure are computed for an antiferromagnetic and thenferromagnetic phase and compared with the experiment.
The strong Hubbard-typenrepulsion on the Mn-3d orbitals and the p-d hybridization are seen to benresponsible for substantial defects found in the LSDA picture.
It is discussednto which extent these can be improved upon by means of the GW approach.n

authors: A. Czarnecki, W. J. Marciano, and A. Sirlin
title: Electroweak Radiative Corrections to Muon Capture
abstract: Electroweak radiative corrections to muon capture on nuclei are computed andnfound to be sizable.
They enhance the capture rates for hydrogen and helium byn2.8% and 3.0% respectively.

As a result, the value of the induced pseudoscalarncoupling, g_P^exp, extracted from a recent hydrogen 1S singlet capturenexperiment is increased by about 21% to g_P^exp = 7.3 +/- 1.2 and brought intongood agreement with the prediction of chiral perturbation theory,ng_P^theory=8.2 +/- 0.2.
Implications for helium capture rate predictions arenalso discussed.n

authors: Sheng Yang and Jean-Claude Belfiore
title: Diversity of MIMO Multihop Relay Channels - Part I: Amplify-and-Forward
abstract: In this two-part paper, we consider the multiantenna multihop relay channelsnin which the source signal arrives at the destination through N independentnrelaying hops in series.
The main concern of this work is to design relayingnstrategies that utilize efficiently the relays in such a way that the diversitynis maximized.
In part I, we focus on the amplify-and-forward (AF) strategy withnwhich the relays simply scale the received signal and retransmit it.
Morenspecifically, we characterize the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff (DMT) of thenAF scheme in a general multihop channel with arbitrary number of antennas andnarbitrary number of hops.
The DMT is in closed-form expression as a function ofnthe number of antennas at each node.
First, we provide some basic results onnthe DMT of the general Rayleigh product channels.
It turns out that thesenresults have very simple and intuitive interpretation.
Then, the results arenapplied to the AF multihop channels which is shown to be equivalent to thenRayleigh product channel, in the DMT sense.
Finally, the project-and-forwardn(PF) scheme, a variant of the AF scheme, is proposed.
We show that the PFnscheme has the same DMT as the AF scheme, while the PF can have significantnpower gain over the AF scheme in some cases.
In part II, we will derive thenupper bound on the diversity of the multihop channels and show that it can benachieved by partitioning the multihop channel into AF subchannels.n

authors: R Springell, S W Zochowski, R C C Ward, M R Wells, S D Brown, Ln  Bouchenoire, F Wilhelm, S Langridge, W G Stirling and G H Lander
title: A study of uranium-based multilayers: II. Magnetic properties
abstract: SQUID magnetometry and polarised neutron reflectivity measurements have beennemployed to characterise the magnetic properties of U/Fe, U/Co and U/Gdnmultilayers.
The field dependence of the magnetisation was measured at 10K innmagnetic fields from -70kOe to 70kOe.
A temperature dependent study of thenmagnetisation evolution was undertaken for a selection of U/Gd samples.
PNR wasncarried out in a field of 4.4kOe for U/Fe and U/Co samples (at roomntemperature) and for U/Gd samples (at 10K).
Magnetic dead layers of about 15nAngstrom were observed for U/Fe and U/Co samples, consistent with a picture ofninterdiffused interfaces.
A large reduction in the magnetic moment, constantnover a wide range of Gd layer thicknesses, was found for the U/Gd system (aboutn4 Bohr magnetons compared with 7.63 for the bulk metal).
This could benunderstood on the basis of a pinning of Gd moments arising from a column-likengrowth mechanism of the Gd layers.
A study of the effective anisotropy suggestsnthat perpendicular magnetic anisotropy could occur in multilayers consisting ofnthick U and thin Gd layers.
A reduction in the Curie temperature was observednas a function of Gd layer thickness, consistent with a finite-size scalingnbehaviour.n

authors: Ch. Strelow, C. M. Schultz, H. Rehberg, H. Welsch, Ch. Heyn, D.n  Heitmann and T. Kipp
title: Three-Dimensionally Confined Optical Modes in Quantum Well Microtuben  Ring Resonators
abstract: We report on microtube ring resonators with quantum wells embedded as annoptically active material.
Optical modes are observed over a broad energynrange.
Their properties strongly depend on the exact geometry of the microtubenalong its axis.

In particular we observe (i) preferential emission of light onnthe inside edge of the microtube and (ii) confinement of light also inndirection of the tube axis by an axially varying geometry which is explained innan expanded waveguide model.n

authors: P.J. Salazar-Valencia, L.E. Bolivar-Marinez, and S.T.n  Perez-Merchancano
title: Electronic Emition Properties of Bi Layer Novel Organic Semiconductorn  Systems
abstract: The perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic-dianhydride (PTCDA) andn1,4,5,8-naphthalene-tetracaboxylic-dianhydride (NTCDA) are planar pi-stackingnorganic molecules that have been shown to be excellent model compounds fornstudying the growth and optoelectronic properties of organic semiconductor thinnfilms, particularly organic diodes.

Some observations have shown that thisnmolecules, particularly PTCDA a brick-like shaped molecule easily formsnwell-ordered films on various substrates due to its unique crystal structurenwhich is characterized by flat lying molecules In this work we will explorensome energetic and optical characteristics such as heats of formation, opticnGAP energies, electronic transitions and others of novel tow layer systems ofnalternate layers of PTCDA and NTCDA by means of the semiempirical methodsnParametric Model 3 (PM3) and Zerners Intermediate Neglect of DifferentialnOverlap (ZINDO/S) in Configuration Interaction mode.n

authors: Julian A. Zu~niga, O.L. Hernandez-Rosero, and S.T. Perez-Merchancano
title: Rectangular Potential Barrier Affected by External Fields, Hydrostaticn  Pressure and Impurities
abstract: In this work the influence of the electric and magnetic fields over antunneling particle in a rectangular potential barrier is shown, we have takenninto account the presence of an impurity at the barrier center and the effectsnof a hydrostatic pressure parallel to the barrier height considering thenBenDaniel-Duke boundary conditions.

Given that the particle is moving inside anGaAs-AlxGa1-xAs-GaAs heterostructures it is evident a change in thentransmission coefficient due to the impurity concentration and the presence ofnthe hydrostatic pressure.
The potential due to the presence of the impurity isnapproximate with a second degree polynomial function that resolves thendiscontinuity generated by heavily modifying the transmission coefficient.n

authors: Audrey Cottet
title: Spectroscopy and critical temperature of diffusiven  superconducting/ferromagnetic hybrid structures with spin-active interfaces
abstract: The description of the proximity effect in superconducting/ferromagneticnheterostructures requires to use spin-dependent boundary conditions.

Suchnboundary conditions must take into account the spin dependence of the phasenshifts acquired by electrons upon scattering on the boundaries of ferromagnets.nThe present article shows that this property can strongly affect the criticalntemperature and the energy dependence of the density of states of diffusivenheterostructures.
These effects should allow a better caracterisation ofndiffusive superconductor/ferromagnet interfaces.n

authors: Maria Manuel Clementino (University of Coimbra) and Dirk Hofmannn  (University of Aveiro)
title: Lawvere completeness in Topology
abstract: It is known since 1973 that Lawveres notion of (Cauchy-)complete enrichedncategory is meaningful for metric spaces: it captures exactly Cauchy-completenmetric spaces.

In this paper we introduce the corresponding notion of Lawverencompleteness for $(mathbb{T},mathsf{V})$-categories and show that it has anninteresting meaning for topological spaces and quasi-uniform spaces: for thenformer ones means weak sobriety while for the latter means Cauchy completeness.nFurther, we show that $mathsf{V}$ has a canonicaln$(mathbb{T},mathsf{V})$-category structure which plays a key role: it isnLawvere-complete under reasonable conditions on the setting; permits us tondefine a Yoneda embedding in the realm of $(mathbb{T},mathsf{V})$-categories.n

authors: M.M. Falla Solorzano, L.E. Bolivar-Marinez, and S.T.n  Perez-Merchancano
title: Electronic Properties of Eumelanin Monomers and Dimmers
abstract: The melanin is a group of biological pigments commonly found in livingnbeings, it can be classified in three groups: eumelanin human beings,npheomelanins in animals, and allomelanins in the vegetal kingdom.
There is anspecial interest in the eumelanin because this biopolymer exhibits the typicalnproperties of a semiconductor.
Eumelanin is also responsible of the mainncellular photoprotection mechanisms in the human beings.

The exact structuralnpattern of eumelanin is not completely known yet, the planar molecules 5,n6-indolquinine and its reduced forms semiquinone and hydroquinone outline thengreater part of the biological pigment.

In this work the structural, electronicnand optical properties of monomers in various charged states (0, -1) andndimmers of eumelanin in vacuum, are found for the neutral state of charge, bynmeans of the Semiempirical methods MNDO, AM1, PM3 and ZINDO/S-CIn

authors: V. B. Semikoz and J. W. F. Valle
title: Lepton asymmetries and the growth of cosmological seed magnetic fields
abstract: Primordial cosmological hypermagnetic fields polarize the earlyn  Universe plasma prior to the electroweak phase transition (EWPT).n  As a result of the long range parity violating gauge interaction present innthe Standard Model their magnitude gets amplified, opening a new, perturbativenway, of accounting for the observed intergalactic magnetic fields.n

authors: Ben Gripaios and Stephen M. West
title: Anomaly Holography
abstract: We consider, in the effective field theory context, anomalies of gauge fieldntheories on a slice of a five-dimensional, Anti-de Sitter geometry and theirnfour-dimensional, holographic duals.
A consistent effective field theoryndescription can always be found, notwithstanding the presence of the anomaliesnand without modifying the degrees of freedom of the theory.

If anomalies do notnvanish, the d=4 theory contains additional pseudoscalar states, which areneither present in the low-energy theory as physical, light states, or are eatennby (would-be massless) gauge bosons.

We show that the pseudoscalars ensure thatnglobal anomalies of the four-dimensional dual satisfy the t Hooft matchingncondition and comment on the relevance for warped models of electroweaknsymmetry breaking.n

authors: Hanfei Yan, Jorg Maser, Albert Macrander, Qun Shen, Stefan Vogt, Briann  Stephenson and Hyon Chol Kang
title: Takagi-Taupin Description of X-ray Dynamical Diffraction fromn  Diffractive Optics with Large Numerical Aperture
abstract: We present a formalism of x-ray dynamical diffraction from volume diffractivenoptics with large numerical aperture and high aspect ratio, in an analogy tonthe Takagi-Taupin equations for strained single crystals.
We derive a set ofnbasic equations for dynamical diffraction from volume diffractive optics, whichnenable us to study the focusing property of these optics with various gratingnprofiles.
We study volume diffractive optics that satisfy the Bragg conditionnto various degrees, namely flat, tilted and wedged geometries, and derive thencurved geometries required for ultimate focusing.
We show that the curvedngeometries satisfy the Bragg condition everywhere and phase requirement fornpoint focusing, and effectively focus hard x-rays to a scale close to thenwavelength.n

authors: Boris Krippa
title: Exact renormalisation group flow for ultracold Fermi gases in unitaryn  limit
abstract: We study the exact renormalisation group flow for ultracold Fermi-gases innunitary regime.
We introduce a pairing field to describe the formation of thenCooper pairs, and take a simple ansatz for the effective action.
Set ofnapproximate flow equations for the effective couplings including boson andnfermionic fluctuations is derived.
At some value of the running scale, thensystem undergoes a phase transition to a gapped phase.
The values of the energyndensity, chemical potential, pairing gap and the corresponding proportionalitynconstants relating the interacting and non-interacting Fermi gases arencalculated.
Standard mean field results are recovered if we omit the bosonnloops.n

authors: I. Bakas, C. Sourdis
title: Dirichlet sigma models and mean curvature flow
abstract: The mean curvature flow describes the parabolic deformation of embeddednbranes in Riemannian geometry driven by their extrinsic mean curvature vector,nwhich is typically associated to surface tension forces.

It is the gradientnflow of the area functional, and, as such, it is naturally identified with thenboundary renormalization group equation of Dirichlet sigma models away fromnconformality, to lowest order in perturbation theory.
D-branes appear as fixednpoints of this flow having conformally invariant boundary conditions.

Simplenrunning solutions include the paper-clip and the hair-pin (or grim-reaper)nmodels on the plane, as well as scaling solutions associated to rational (p, q)nclosed curves and the decay of two intersecting lines.
Stability analysis isnperformed in several cases while searching for transitions among differentnbrane configurations.
The combination of Ricci with the mean curvature flow isnexamined in detail together with several explicit examples of deforming curvesnon curved backgrounds.
Some general aspects of the mean curvature flow innhigher dimensional ambient spaces are also discussed and obtain consistentntruncations to lower dimensional systems.
Selected physical applications arenmentioned in the text, including tachyon condensation in open string theory andnthe resistive diffusion of force-free fields in magneto-hydrodynamics.n

authors: Sergiu I. Vacaru
title: Parametric Nonholonomic Frame Transforms and Exact Solutions in Gravity
abstract: A generalized geometric method is developed for constructing exact solutionsnof gravitational field equations in Einstein theory and generalizations.

First,nwe apply the formalism of nonholonomic frame deformations (formally considerednfor nonholonomic manifolds and Finsler spaces) when the gravitational fieldnequations transform into systems of nonlinear partial differential equationsnwhich can be integrated in general form.

The new classes of solutions arendefined by generic off-diagonal metrics depending on integration functions onnone, two and three (or three and four) variables if we consider four (or five)ndimensional spacetimes.
Second, we use a general scheme when one (two)nparameter families of exact solutions are defined by any source-free solutionsnof Einsteins equations with one (two) Killing vector field(s).
A successiveniteration procedure results in new classes of solutions characterized by anninfinite number of parameters for a non-Abelian group involving arbitrarynfunctions on one variable.
Five classes of exact off-diagonal solutions arenconstructed in vacuum Einstein and in string gravity describing solitonicnpp-wave interactions.
We explore possible physical consequences of suchnsolutions derived from primary Schwarzschild or pp-wave metrics.n

authors: Ana Firan and Ryszard Stroynowski
title: Internal conversions in Higgs decays to two photons
abstract: We evaluate the partial widths for internal conversions in the Higgs decaysnto two photons.
For the Higgs masses of interest at LHC in the range of 100-150nGeV, the conversions to pairs of fermions represent significant fraction ofnHiggs decays.n

authors: Nathanial P. Brown and Andrew S. Toms
title: Three Applications of the Cuntz Semigroup
abstract: Building on work of Elliott and coworkers, we present three applications ofnthe Cuntz semigroup: (i) for many simple C$^*$-algebras, the Thomsen semigroupnis recovered functorially from the Elliott invariant, and this yields a newnproof of Elliotts classification theorem for simple, unital AI algebras; (ii)nfor the algebras in (i), classification of their Hilbert modules is similar tonthe von Neumann algebra context; (iii) for the algebras in (i), approximatenunitary equivalence of self-adjoint operators is characterised in terms of thenElliott invariant.n

authors: Michael Robinson
title: Instability of an equilibrium of a partial differential equation
abstract: A nonlinear parabolic differential equation with a quadratic nonlinearity isnpresented which has at least one equilibrium.
The linearization about thisnequilibrium is asymptotically stable, but by using a technique inspired by H.nFujita, we show that the equilibrium is unstable in the nonlinear setting.
Thenperturbations used have the property that they are small in every $L^p$ norm,nyet they result in solutions which fail to be global.n

authors: A. Kogut, J. Dunkley, C. L. Bennett, O. Dore, B. Gold, M. Halpern,n  G. Hinshaw, N. Jarosik, E. Komatsu, M. R. Nolta, N. Odegard, L. Page, D. N.n  Spergel, G. S. Tucker, J. L. Weiland, E. Wollack, E. L. Wright
title: Three-Year Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) Observations:n  Foreground Polarization
abstract: We present a full-sky model of polarized Galactic microwave emission based onnthree years of observations by the Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP)nat frequencies from 23 to 94 GHz.

The model compares maps of the Stokes Q and Uncomponents from each of the 5 WMAP frequency bands in order to separatensynchrotron from dust emission, taking into account the spatial and frequencyndependence of the synchrotron and dust components.
This simple two-componentnmodel of the interstellar medium accounts for at least 97% of the polarizednemission in the WMAP maps of the microwave sky.
Synchrotron emission dominatesnthe polarized foregrounds at frequencies below 50 GHz, and is comparable to thendust contribution at 65 GHz.
The spectral index of the synchrotron component,nderived solely from polarization data, is -3.2 averaged over the full sky, withna modestly flatter index on the Galactic plane.

The synchrotron emission hasnmean polarization fraction 2--4% in the Galactic plane and rising to over 20%nat high latitude, with prominent features such as the North Galactic Spur morenpolarized than the diffuse component.
Thermal dust emission has polarizationnfraction 1% near the Galactic center, rising to 6% at the anti-center.
Diffusenemission from high-latitude dust is also polarized with mean fractionalnpolarization 0.036 +/- 0.011.n

authors: Lev Birbrair, Dirk Siersma
title: Metric Properties of Conflict Sets
abstract: In this paper we show that the tangent cone of a conflict set in $R^n$ is anlinear affine cone over a conflict set of smaller dimension and has dimensionn$n-1$.
Moreover we give an example where the conflict sets is not normallynembedded and not locally bi-Lipschitz equivalent to the corresponding tangentncone.n

authors: S. N. Fedosov, A. E. Sergeeva, A. F. Butenko
title: Depolarization Currents in Fresh and Aged Corona Poled P(VDF-TFE) Films
abstract: Using short circuit and open circuit modifications of the thermallynstimulated depolarization current technique, relaxation currents have beennmeasured in corona poled copolymer of vinylidene fluoride withntetrafluoroethylene in samples stored after poling for either 1 day, or 16nmonth.
Two well structured peaks observed in aged samples were attributed tonrelaxation of electret and ferroelectric components of the remnantnpolarization.
In fresh samples the two components were mixed forming one broadnpeak.
Relaxation of the space charge caused inversion of the current in thenopen circuit mode both in fresh and in aged samples.
Space charge peaksnextracted from the total current by appropriate calculations have shown thatnthe trapped charges were more stable than the polarization.
